baseline: The definition and usage of socialism settled by the 1860s, replacing associationist, co-operative, mutualist and collectivist that had been used as synonyms while communism fell out of use during this period.

prompts: An early distinction between communism and socialism was that the latter
baseline: An early distinction between communism and socialism was that the latter aimed to only socialise production while the former aimed to socialise both production and consumption (in the form of free access to final goods).

prompts: By 1888 , Marxists employed socialism in place of communism as the latter had come to be considered
baseline: By 1888, Marxists employed socialism in place of communism as the latter had come to be considered an old-fashioned synonym for socialism.

prompts: It was not until after the Bolshevik Revolution that socialism was appropriated by Vladimir Lenin
baseline: It was not until after the Bolshevik Revolution that socialism was appropriated by Vladimir Lenin to mean a stage between capitalism and communism.

prompts: The distinction between communism and socialism became salient in 1918
baseline: The distinction between communism and socialism became salient in 1918 after the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party renamed itself to the All-Russian Communist Party, interpreting communism specifically to mean socialists who supported the politics and theories of Bolshevism, Leninism and later that of Marxism–Leninism, although communist parties continued to describe themselves as socialists dedicated to socialism.

prompts: According to The Oxford Handbook of Karl Marx , " Marx used many terms to
baseline: According to The Oxford Handbook of Karl Marx, "Marx used many terms to refer to a post-capitalist society—positive humanism, socialism, communism, realm of free individuality, free association of producers, etc.

prompts: The notion that ' socialism ' and ' communism ' are distinct historical stages is alien to his
baseline: The notion that 'socialism' and 'communism' are distinct historical stages is alien to his work and only entered the lexicon of Marxism after his death".

prompts: Engels wrote that in 1848 , when The Communist Manifesto was published , socialism was
baseline: Engels wrote that in 1848, when The Communist Manifesto was published, socialism was respectable in Europe while communism was not.

prompts: This branch of socialism produced the communist work
baseline: This branch of socialism produced the communist work of Étienne Cabet in France and Wilhelm Weitling in Germany.

prompts: British moral philosopher John Stuart Mill discussed a form of
baseline: British moral philosopher John Stuart Mill discussed a form of economic socialism within free market.

prompts: The history of socialism has its origins in the Age of Enlightenment and the 1789 French Revolution , along with the changes that brought , although it
baseline: The history of socialism has its origins in the Age of Enlightenment and the 1789 French Revolution, along with the changes that brought, although it has precedents in earlier movements and ideas.

prompts: The Communist Manifesto was written by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels in 1847 - 48 just before the Revolutions of 1848 swept Europe , expressing
baseline: The Communist Manifesto was written by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels in 1847-48 just before the Revolutions of 1848 swept Europe, expressing what they termed scientific socialism.

prompts: In the last third of the 19th century parties dedicated to Democratic socialism
baseline: In the last third of the 19th century parties dedicated to Democratic socialism arose in Europe, drawing mainly from Marxism.

prompts: In the first half of the 20th century , the Soviet Union and the communist parties of the Third International around the world , came to represent socialism
baseline: In the first half of the 20th century, the Soviet Union and the communist parties of the Third International around the world, came to represent socialism in terms of the Soviet model of economic development and the creation of centrally planned economies directed by a state that owns all the means of production, although other trends condemned what they saw as the lack of democracy.

prompts: In the UK , Herbert Morrison said that " socialism
baseline: In the UK, Herbert Morrison said that "socialism is what the Labour government does" whereas Aneurin Bevan argued socialism requires that the "main streams of economic activity are brought under public direction", with an economic plan and workers' democracy.

prompts: Member parties ruling countries included the Front for Victory in Argentina , the PAIS Alliance in Ecuador , Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front in El Salvador , Peru Wins in Peru , and the United Socialist Party of Venezuela , whose leader Hugo Chávez initiated what he called
baseline: Member parties ruling countries included the Front for Victory in Argentina, the PAIS Alliance in Ecuador, Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front in El Salvador, Peru Wins in Peru, and the United Socialist Party of Venezuela, whose leader Hugo Chávez initiated what he called "Socialism of the 21st century".

prompts: Bhaskar Sunkara , the founding editor of the American socialist magazine Jacobin , argued that the appeal
baseline: Bhaskar Sunkara, the founding editor of the American socialist magazine Jacobin, argued that the appeal of socialism persists due to the inequality and "tremendous suffering" under current global capitalism, the use of wage labor "which rests on the exploitation and domination of humans by other humans," and ecological crises, such as climate change.

prompts: Perry of the conservative American Enterprise Institute ( AEI ) argued that despite socialism
baseline: Perry of the conservative American Enterprise Institute (AEI) argued that despite socialism's resurgence, it is still "a flawed system based on completely faulty principles that aren't consistent with human behavior and can't nurture the human spirit.", adding that "While it promised prosperity, equality, and security, it delivered poverty, misery, and tyranny." Some in the scientific community have suggested that a contemporary radical response to social and ecological problems could be seen in the emergence of movements associated with degrowth, eco-socialism and eco-anarchism.

prompts: Another philosophical basis for a great deal of early socialism was the emergence of
baseline: Another philosophical basis for a great deal of early socialism was the emergence of positivism during the European Enlightenment.

prompts: The fundamental objective of socialism is to attain an advanced level
baseline: The fundamental objective of socialism is to attain an advanced level of material production and therefore greater productivity, efficiency and rationality as compared to capitalism and all previous systems, under the view that an expansion of human productive capability is the basis for the extension of freedom and equality in society.

prompts: In particular , socialism holds that social mores
baseline: In particular, socialism holds that social mores, values, cultural traits and economic practices are social creations and not the result of an immutable natural law.

prompts: Russell opposed the class struggle aspects of Marxism , viewing socialism solely as
baseline: Russell opposed the class struggle aspects of Marxism, viewing socialism solely as an adjustment of economic relations to accommodate modern machine production to benefit all of humanity through the progressive reduction of necessary work time.

prompts: Karl Marx believed that expansion of the productive forces and technology was the basis for the expansion of human freedom and that socialism , being a system that is consistent with modern developments in technology , would enable the flourishing of
baseline: Karl Marx believed that expansion of the productive forces and technology was the basis for the expansion of human freedom and that socialism, being a system that is consistent with modern developments in technology, would enable the flourishing of "free individualities" through the progressive reduction of necessary labour time.

prompts: Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels argued that socialism would emerge from historical necessity
baseline: Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels argued that socialism would emerge from historical necessity as capitalism rendered itself obsolete and unsustainable from increasing internal contradictions emerging from the development of the productive forces and technology.

prompts: Marx and Engels used the terms socialism and communism interchangeably , but many later Marxists defined socialism as a
baseline: Marx and Engels used the terms socialism and communism interchangeably, but many later Marxists defined socialism as a specific historical phase that would displace capitalism and precede communism.

prompts: The major characteristics of socialism ( particularly as conceived by Marx and Engels after the Paris Commune of 1871 ) are that the proletariat
baseline: The major characteristics of socialism (particularly as conceived by Marx and Engels after the Paris Commune of 1871) are that the proletariat would control the means of production through a workers' state erected by the workers in their interests.

prompts: For orthodox Marxists , socialism is the lower stage of communism based on the principle
baseline: For orthodox Marxists, socialism is the lower stage of communism based on the principle of "from each according to his ability, to each according to his contribution" while upper stage communism is based on the principle of "from each according to his ability, to each according to his need", the upper stage becoming possible only after the socialist stage further develops economic efficiency and the automation of production has led to a superabundance of goods and services.

prompts: Socialists have taken different perspectives on the state and the role it should play in revolutionary struggles
baseline: Socialists have taken different perspectives on the state and the role it should play in revolutionary struggles, in constructing socialism and within an established socialist economy.

prompts: In the 19th century , the philosophy of state socialism was first explicitly expounded by the German
baseline: In the 19th century, the philosophy of state socialism was first explicitly expounded by the German political philosopher Ferdinand Lassalle.

prompts: Preceding the Bolshevik - led revolution in Russia , many socialists including reformists , orthodox
baseline: Preceding the Bolshevik-led revolution in Russia, many socialists including reformists, orthodox Marxist currents such as council communism, anarchists and libertarian socialists criticised the idea of using the state to conduct central planning and own the means of production as a way to establish socialism.

prompts: Following the victory of Leninism in Russia , the idea of " state socialism " spread rapidly throughout the
baseline: Following the victory of Leninism in Russia, the idea of "state socialism" spread rapidly throughout the socialist movement and eventually state socialism came to be identified with the Soviet economic model.

prompts: Joseph Schumpeter rejected the association of socialism and social ownership with state ownership over the means of production because the state as it exists in its current
baseline: Joseph Schumpeter rejected the association of socialism and social ownership with state ownership over the means of production because the state as it exists in its current form is a product of capitalist society and cannot be transplanted to a different institutional framework.

prompts: Schumpeter argued that there would be different institutions within socialism than those that exist within modern capitalism
baseline: Schumpeter argued that there would be different institutions within socialism than those that exist within modern capitalism, just as feudalism had its own distinct and unique institutional forms.

prompts: Utopian socialism is a term used to define the first currents
baseline: Utopian socialism is a term used to define the first currents of modern socialist thought as exemplified by the work of Henri de Saint-Simon, Charles Fourier and Robert Owen which inspired Karl Marx and other early socialists.

prompts: For Marxists , the development of capitalism in Western Europe provided a material basis
baseline: For Marxists, the development of capitalism in Western Europe provided a material basis for the possibility of bringing about socialism because according to The Communist Manifesto "hat the bourgeoisie produces above all is its own grave diggers", namely the working class, which must become conscious of the historical objectives set it by society.

prompts: Reformism is generally associated with social democracy
baseline: Reformism is generally associated with social democracy and gradualist democratic socialism.

prompts: Within socialism , reformism is used in two different
baseline: Within socialism, reformism is used in two different ways.

prompts: One has no intention of bringing about socialism or fundamental economic change to society and is used to oppose such
baseline: One has no intention of bringing about socialism or fundamental economic change to society and is used to oppose such structural changes.

prompts: The other is based on the assumption that while reforms are not socialist in themselves , they can help rally supporters to
baseline: The other is based on the assumption that while reforms are not socialist in themselves, they can help rally supporters to the cause of revolution by popularizing the cause of socialism to the working class.

prompts: Under Socialism , solidarity will be the basis of
baseline: Under Socialism, solidarity will be the basis of society.

prompts: Albert Einstein advocated for a socialist planned economy with his
baseline: Albert Einstein advocated for a socialist planned economy with his 1949 article "Why Socialism?"

prompts: The original conception of socialism was an economic system whereby production was organised in a way
baseline: The original conception of socialism was an economic system whereby production was organised in a way to directly produce goods and services for their utility (or use-value in classical and Marxian economics), with the direct allocation of resources in terms of physical units as opposed to financial calculation and the economic laws of capitalism (see law of value), often entailing the end of capitalistic economic categories such as rent, interest, profit and money.

prompts: Market socialism refers to an array of different economic theories and systems that use the market mechanism
baseline: Market socialism refers to an array of different economic theories and systems that use the market mechanism to organise production and to allocate factor inputs among socially owned enterprises, with the economic surplus (profits) accruing to society in a social dividend as opposed to private capital owners.

prompts: Variations of market socialism include libertarian proposals such as mutualism , based on classical economics
baseline: Variations of market socialism include libertarian proposals such as mutualism, based on classical economics, and neoclassical economic models such as the Lange Model.

prompts: Some economists , such as Joseph Stiglitz , Mancur Olson , and others not specifically advancing anti - socialists
baseline: Some economists, such as Joseph Stiglitz, Mancur Olson, and others not specifically advancing anti-socialists positions have shown that prevailing economic models upon which such democratic or market socialism models might be based have logical flaws or unworkable presuppositions.

prompts: These criticisms have been incorporated into the models of market socialism developed by John Roemer
baseline: These criticisms have been incorporated into the models of market socialism developed by John Roemer and Nicholas Vrousalis.

prompts: State socialism is unfeasible in this view because information can not be aggregated by a central
baseline: State socialism is unfeasible in this view because information cannot be aggregated by a central body and effectively used to formulate a plan for an entire economy, because doing so would result in distorted or absent price signals.

prompts: Socialism , you see , is a
baseline: Socialism, you see, is a bird with two wings.

prompts: Guild socialism is a political movement advocating workers ' control
baseline: Guild socialism is a political movement advocating workers' control of industry through the medium of trade-related guilds "in an implied contractual relationship with the public".

prompts: A contemporary model for a self - managed , non -
baseline: A contemporary model for a self-managed, non-market socialism is Pat Devine's model of negotiated coordination.

prompts: Wolff argues that " re - organising production so that workers become collectively self -
baseline: Wolff argues that "re-organising production so that workers become collectively self-directed at their work-sites" not only moves society beyond both capitalism and state socialism of the last century, but would also mark another milestone in human history, similar to earlier transitions out of slavery and feudalism.

prompts: State socialism can be used to classify any variety of
baseline: State socialism can be used to classify any variety of socialist philosophies that advocates the ownership of the means of production by the state apparatus, either as a transitional stage between capitalism and socialism, or as an end-goal in itself.

prompts: Market socialism consists of publicly owned or cooperatively owned enterprises operating in
baseline: Market socialism consists of publicly owned or cooperatively owned enterprises operating in a market economy.

prompts: In state - oriented forms of market socialism , in which state enterprises attempt to maximise profit
baseline: In state-oriented forms of market socialism, in which state enterprises attempt to maximise profit, the profits can be used to fund government programs and services through a social dividend, eliminating or greatly diminishing the need for various forms of taxation that exist in capitalist systems.

prompts: Some of the economic reforms introduced during the Prague Spring by Alexander Dubček , the leader of Czechoslovakia , included elements of market
baseline: Some of the economic reforms introduced during the Prague Spring by Alexander Dubček, the leader of Czechoslovakia, included elements of market socialism.

prompts: While major socialist political movements include anarchism , communism , the labour movement , Marxism , social democracy , and syndicalism , independent socialist theorists , utopian socialist authors , and academic supporters of socialism may not be represented in these movements
baseline: While major socialist political movements include anarchism, communism, the labour movement, Marxism, social democracy, and syndicalism, independent socialist theorists, utopian socialist authors, and academic supporters of socialism may not be represented in these movements.

prompts: Some political groups have called themselves socialist while holding views that some
baseline: Some political groups have called themselves socialist while holding views that some consider antithetical to socialism.

prompts: While there are many variations of socialism , and there is no single definition
baseline: While there are many variations of socialism, and there is no single definition encapsulating all of socialism, there have been common elements identified by scholars.

prompts: Rappoport analysed forty definitions of socialism to conclude that common elements
baseline: Rappoport analysed forty definitions of socialism to conclude that common elements of socialism include general criticism of the social effects of private ownership and control of capital—as being the cause of poverty, low wages, unemployment, economic and social inequality and a lack of economic security; a general view that the solution to these problems is a form of collective control over the means of production, distribution and exchange (the degree and means of control vary among socialist movements); an agreement that the outcome of this collective control should be a society based upon social justice, including social equality, economic protection of people and should provide a more satisfying life for most people.

prompts: In The Concepts of Socialism ( 1975 ) , Bhikhu Parekh identifies four core principles
baseline: In The Concepts of Socialism (1975), Bhikhu Parekh identifies four core principles of socialism and particularly socialist society, namely sociality, social responsibility, cooperation and planning.

prompts: In his study Ideologies and Political Theory ( 1996 ) , Michael Freeden states that all socialists
baseline: In his study Ideologies and Political Theory (1996), Michael Freeden states that all socialists share five themes: the first is that socialism posits that society is more than a mere collection of individuals; second, that it considers human welfare a desirable objective; third, that it considers humans by nature to be active and productive; fourth, it holds the belief of human equality; and fifth, that history is progressive and will create positive change on the condition that humans work to achieve such change.

prompts: Mutualists support market socialism , collectivist anarchists favour workers cooperatives and
baseline: Mutualists support market socialism, collectivist anarchists favour workers cooperatives and salaries based on the amount of time contributed to production, anarcho-communists advocate a direct transition from capitalism to libertarian communism and a gift economy and anarcho-syndicalists prefer workers' direct action and the general strike.

prompts: In 1888 , the individualist anarchist Benjamin Tucker , who proclaimed himself to be
baseline: In 1888, the individualist anarchist Benjamin Tucker, who proclaimed himself to be an anarchistic socialist and libertarian socialist in opposition to the authoritarian state socialism and the compulsory communism, included the full text of a "Socialistic Letter" by Ernest Lesigne in his essay on "State Socialism and Anarchism".

prompts: According to Lesigne , there are two types of socialism : " One is dictatorial , the
baseline: According to Lesigne, there are two types of socialism: "One is dictatorial, the other libertarian".

prompts: Tucker 's two socialisms were the authoritarian state socialism which he associated to the Marxist
baseline: Tucker's two socialisms were the authoritarian state socialism which he associated to the Marxist school and the libertarian anarchist socialism, or simply anarchism, that he advocated.

prompts: Tucker noted that the fact that the authoritarian " State Socialism has overshadowed other forms of
baseline: Tucker noted that the fact that the authoritarian "State Socialism has overshadowed other forms of Socialism gives it no right to a monopoly of the Socialistic idea".

prompts: According to Tucker , what those two schools of socialism had in common was the labor theory
baseline: According to Tucker, what those two schools of socialism had in common was the labor theory of value and the ends, by which anarchism pursued different means.

prompts: According to anarchists such as the authors of An Anarchist FAQ , anarchism is one of the
baseline: According to anarchists such as the authors of An Anarchist FAQ, anarchism is one of the many traditions of socialism.

prompts: For anarchists and other anti - authoritarian socialists , socialism " can only mean a classless and
baseline: For anarchists and other anti-authoritarian socialists, socialism "can only mean a classless and anti-authoritarian (i.e. libertarian) society in which people manage their own affairs, either as individuals or as part of a group (depending on the situation).

prompts: Peter Marshall argues that " n
baseline: Peter Marshall argues that "n general anarchism is closer to socialism than liberalism. ...

prompts: It can not be reduced to socialism , and is best seen as a separate
baseline: It cannot be reduced to socialism, and is best seen as a separate and distinctive doctrine."

prompts: There must be a better distribution of wealth , and maybe America must move toward a democratic
baseline: There must be a better distribution of wealth, and maybe America must move toward a democratic socialism.

prompts: Democratic socialism represents any socialist movement that seeks to establish an
baseline: Democratic socialism represents any socialist movement that seeks to establish an economy based on economic democracy by and for the working class.

prompts: Democratic socialism is difficult to define and groups of scholars have radically different definitions
baseline: Democratic socialism is difficult to define and groups of scholars have radically different definitions for the term.

prompts: Some definitions simply refer to all forms of socialism that follow an electoral ,
baseline: Some definitions simply refer to all forms of socialism that follow an electoral, reformist or evolutionary path to socialism rather than a revolutionary one.

prompts: According to Christopher Pierson , " f the contrast which 1989 highlights is not that between socialism in the East and liberal democracy in the West , the latter must be recognised to have been
baseline: According to Christopher Pierson, "f the contrast which 1989 highlights is not that between socialism in the East and liberal democracy in the West, the latter must be recognised to have been shaped, reformed and compromised by a century of social democratic pressure".

prompts: For Pierson , " if advocates of the death of socialism accept that social democrats
baseline: For Pierson, "if advocates of the death of socialism accept that social democrats belong within the socialist camp, as I think they must, then the contrast between socialism (in all its variants) and liberal democracy must collapse.

prompts: The two main directions were to establish democratic socialism or
baseline: The two main directions were to establish democratic socialism or to build first a welfare state within the capitalist system.

prompts: The first variant advances democratic socialism through
baseline: The first variant advances democratic socialism through reformist and gradualist methods.

prompts: Social democrats advocate a peaceful ,
baseline: Social democrats advocate a peaceful, evolutionary transition of the economy to socialism through progressive social reform.

prompts: Modern democratic socialism is a broad political movement that seeks to promote the
baseline: Modern democratic socialism is a broad political movement that seeks to promote the ideals of socialism within the context of a democratic system.

prompts: The major difference between social democracy and democratic socialism is the object of
baseline: The major difference between social democracy and democratic socialism is the object of their politics in that contemporary social democrats support a welfare state and unemployment insurance as well as other practical, progressive reforms of capitalism and are more concerned to administrate and humanise it.

prompts: Ethical socialism appeals to socialism on ethical and moral grounds as opposed to economic ,
baseline: Ethical socialism appeals to socialism on ethical and moral grounds as opposed to economic, egoistic, and consumeristic grounds.

prompts: Ethical socialism has been the official philosophy
baseline: Ethical socialism has been the official philosophy of mainstream socialist parties.

prompts: Liberal socialism incorporates liberal principles to
baseline: Liberal socialism incorporates liberal principles to socialism.

prompts: While democratic socialism and social democracy are anti - capitalist positions insofar as criticism of capitalism is linked to the private
baseline: While democratic socialism and social democracy are anti-capitalist positions insofar as criticism of capitalism is linked to the private ownership of the means of production, liberal socialism identifies artificial and legalistic monopolies to be the fault of capitalism and opposes an entirely unregulated market economy.

prompts: Liberal socialism has been particularly prominent in
baseline: Liberal socialism has been particularly prominent in British and Italian politics.

prompts: Hal Draper defined socialism from above as the philosophy which employs an elite administration
baseline: Hal Draper defined socialism from above as the philosophy which employs an elite administration to run the socialist state.

prompts: The other side of socialism is a more democratic
baseline: The other side of socialism is a more democratic socialism from below.

prompts: The idea of socialism from above is much more frequently
baseline: The idea of socialism from above is much more frequently discussed in elite circles than socialism from below—even if that is the Marxist ideal—because it is more practical.

prompts: Draper viewed socialism from below
baseline: Draper viewed socialism from below as being the purer, more Marxist version of socialism.

prompts: Draper makes the argument that this division echoes the division between
baseline: Draper makes the argument that this division echoes the division between "reformist or revolutionary, peaceful or violent, democratic or authoritarian, etc." and further identifies six major varieties of socialism from above, among them "Philanthropism", "Elitism", "Pannism", "Communism", "Permeationism" and "Socialism-from-Outside".

prompts: According to Arthur Lipow , Marx and Engels were " the founders
baseline: According to Arthur Lipow, Marx and Engels were "the founders of modern revolutionary democratic socialism", described as a form of "socialism from below" that is "based on a mass working-class movement, fighting from below for the extension of democracy and human freedom".

prompts: This type of socialism is contrasted to that of the " authoritarian , anti - democratic creed " and " the various totalitarian collectivist ideologies which claim the
baseline: This type of socialism is contrasted to that of the "authoritarian, anti-democratic creed" and "the various totalitarian collectivist ideologies which claim the title of socialism" as well as "the many varieties of 'socialism from above' which have led in the twentieth century to movements and state forms in which a despotic 'new class' rules over a stratified economy in the name of socialism", a division that "runs through the history of the socialist movement".

prompts: Libertarian socialism , sometimes called left - libertarianism , social anarchism and socialist libertarianism , is an anti - authoritarian , anti - statist and libertarian tradition within socialism that rejects centralised state ownership
baseline: Libertarian socialism, sometimes called left-libertarianism, social anarchism and socialist libertarianism, is an anti-authoritarian, anti-statist and libertarian tradition within socialism that rejects centralised state ownership and control including criticism of wage labour relationships (wage slavery) as well as the state itself.

prompts: Libertarian socialism asserts that a society based on freedom and
baseline: Libertarian socialism asserts that a society based on freedom and equality can be achieved through abolishing authoritarian institutions that control production.

prompts: Past and present political philosophies and movements commonly described as libertarian socialist
baseline: Past and present political philosophies and movements commonly described as libertarian socialist include anarchism (anarcho-communism, anarcho-syndicalism, collectivist anarchism, individualist anarchism and mutualism), autonomism, Communalism, participism, libertarian Marxism (council communism and Luxemburgism), revolutionary syndicalism and utopian socialism (Fourierism).

prompts: Christian socialism is a broad concept involving an intertwining of
baseline: Christian socialism is a broad concept involving an intertwining of Christian religion with socialism.

prompts: Arabic letters " Lam " and " Alif " reading " Lā "
baseline: Arabic letters "Lam" and "Alif" reading "Lā" (Arabic for "No!") are a symbol of Islamic Socialism in Turkey.

prompts: Islamic socialism is a more spiritual
baseline: Islamic socialism is a more spiritual form of socialism.

prompts: In Oscar Wilde 's The Soul of Man Under Socialism , he advocates an egalitarian society
baseline: In Oscar Wilde's The Soul of Man Under Socialism, he advocates an egalitarian society where wealth is shared by all, while warning of the dangers of social systems that crush individuality.

prompts: Eco - socialism is a political strain merging aspects of socialism
baseline: Eco-socialism is a political strain merging aspects of socialism, Marxism or libertarian socialism with green politics, ecology and alter-globalisation.

prompts: English socialist William Morris is credited with developing principles of what
baseline: English socialist William Morris is credited with developing principles of what was later called eco-socialism.

prompts: It rejects state socialism and
baseline: It rejects state socialism and the use of establishment politics.

prompts: A multitude of polls have found significant levels of
baseline: A multitude of polls have found significant levels of support for socialism among modern populations.

prompts: Subsequently , another 2021 Axios poll found that 51 %
baseline: Subsequently, another 2021 Axios poll found that 51% of 18-34 US adults had a positive view of socialism.

prompts: Yet , 41 % of Americans more generally had a positive view
baseline: Yet, 41% of Americans more generally had a positive view of socialism compared to 52% of those who viewing socialism more negatively.

prompts: In 2023 , the Fraser Institute published findings which found
baseline: In 2023, the Fraser Institute published findings which found that 42% of Canadians viewed socialism as the ideal system compared to 43% of British respondents, 40% Australian respondents and 31% American respondents.

prompts: Overall support for socialism ranged from 50 %
baseline: Overall support for socialism ranged from 50% of Canadians 18-24 year olds to 28% of Canadians over 55.

prompts: According to analytical Marxist sociologist Erik Olin Wright , " The Right condemned socialism as violating
baseline: According to analytical Marxist sociologist Erik Olin Wright, "The Right condemned socialism as violating individual rights to private property and unleashing monstrous forms of state oppression", while "the Left saw it as opening up new vistas of social equality, genuine freedom and the development of human potentials."

prompts: Because of socialism 's many varieties , most critiques have focused on a specific
baseline: Because of socialism's many varieties, most critiques have focused on a specific approach.

prompts: Socialism has been criticised in terms of
baseline: Socialism has been criticised in terms of its models of economic organization as well as its political and social implications.

prompts: Critics of socialism have argued that in any society where everyone holds equal wealth ,
baseline: Critics of socialism have argued that in any society where everyone holds equal wealth, there can be no material incentive to work because one does not receive rewards for a work well done.

prompts: Some critics of socialism argue that income sharing reduces individual incentives to
baseline: Some critics of socialism argue that income sharing reduces individual incentives to work and therefore incomes should be individualized as much as possible.

prompts: Some philosophers have also criticized the aims of socialism , arguing that equality erodes
baseline: Some philosophers have also criticized the aims of socialism, arguing that equality erodes away at individual diversities and that the establishment of an equal society would have to entail strong coercion.

prompts: Many commentators on the political right point to the mass killings under communist regimes , claiming them as an
baseline: Many commentators on the political right point to the mass killings under communist regimes, claiming them as an indictment of socialism.

prompts: Opponents of this view , including supporters of socialism , state that these killings
baseline: Opponents of this view, including supporters of socialism, state that these killings were aberrations caused by specific authoritarian regimes, and not caused by socialism itself, and  draw comparisons to killings, famines and excess deaths under capitalism, colonialism and anti-communist authoritarian governments.

prompts: Socialist systems divide into non -
baseline: Socialist systems divide into non-market and market forms.

prompts: A non - market socialist system seeks to eliminate the
baseline: A non-market socialist system seeks to eliminate the perceived inefficiencies, irrationalities, unpredictability, and crises that socialists traditionally associate with capital accumulation and the profit system.

prompts: Socialist parties and ideas remain a political force with varying degrees of power
baseline: Socialist parties and ideas remain a political force with varying degrees of power and influence, heading national governments in several countries.

prompts: Socialist politics have been internationalist and nationalist ; organised through political parties
baseline: Socialist politics have been internationalist and nationalist; organised through political parties and opposed to party politics; at times overlapping with trade unions and other times independent and critical of them, and present in industrialised and developing nations.

prompts: Social democracy originated within the socialist movement , supporting economic and social
baseline: Social democracy originated within the socialist movement, supporting economic and social interventions to promote social justice.

prompts: The socialist political movement includes political philosophies that originated in the revolutionary
baseline: The socialist political movement includes political philosophies that originated in the revolutionary movements of the mid-to-late 18th century and out of concern for the social problems that socialists associated with capitalism.

prompts: By the early 1920s , communism and social democracy had become the two dominant
baseline: By the early 1920s, communism and social democracy had become the two dominant political tendencies within the international socialist movement, with socialism itself becoming the most influential secular movement of the 20th century.

prompts: While the emergence of the Soviet Union as the world 's first nominally socialist state led to socialism 's
baseline: While the emergence of the Soviet Union as the world's first nominally socialist state led to socialism's widespread association with the Soviet economic model, academics have noted that some Western European countries have been governed by socialist parties or have mixed economies that are sometimes called "democratic socialist".

prompts: Following the revolutions of 1989 , many of these countries moved away from socialism
baseline: Following the revolutions of 1989, many of these countries moved away from socialism as a neoliberal consensus replaced the social democratic consensus in the advanced capitalist world, while many former socialist politicians and political parties embraced "Third Way" politics, remaining committed to equality and welfare, while abandoning public ownership and class-based politics.

prompts: In Protestant England , communism was too close to the Roman Catholic communion rite , hence socialist was the preferred term
baseline: In Protestant England, communism was too close to the Roman Catholic communion rite, hence socialist was the preferred term.

prompts: In later editions of his Principles of Political Economy ( 1848 ) , Mill posited that " as
baseline: In later editions of his Principles of Political Economy (1848), Mill posited that "as far as economic theory was concerned, there is nothing in principle in economic theory that precludes an economic order based on socialist policies" and promoted substituting capitalist businesses with worker cooperatives.

prompts: The Australian Labor Party was the first elected socialist party when
baseline: The Australian Labor Party was the first elected socialist party when it formed government in the Colony of Queensland for a week in 1899.

prompts: Socialist governments established the mixed economy
baseline: Socialist governments established the mixed economy with partial nationalisations and social welfare.

prompts: In 1990 , the São Paulo Forum was launched by the Workers
baseline: In 1990, the São Paulo Forum was launched by the Workers' Party (Brazil), linking left-wing socialist parties in Latin America.

baseline: Socialists argue that capitalism consists of irrational activity, such as the purchasing of commodities only to sell at a later time when their price appreciates, rather than for consumption, even if the commodity cannot be sold at a profit to individuals in need and therefore a crucial criticism often made by socialists is that "making money", or accumulation of capital, does not correspond to the satisfaction of demand (the production of use-values).

prompts: The fundamental criterion for economic activity in capitalism is the accumulation of
baseline: The fundamental criterion for economic activity in capitalism is the accumulation of capital for reinvestment in production, but this spurs the development of new, non-productive industries that do not produce use-value and only exist to keep the accumulation process afloat (otherwise the system goes into crisis), such as the spread of the financial industry, contributing to the formation of economic bubbles.

prompts: In essence , social welfare policies cripple capitalism and its
baseline: In essence, social welfare policies cripple capitalism and its incentive system and are thus unsustainable in the long run.

prompts: Early socialists ( utopian socialists and Ricardian socialists ) criticised capitalism for concentrating
baseline: Early socialists (utopian socialists and Ricardian socialists) criticised capitalism for concentrating power and wealth within a small segment of society.

prompts: In addition , they complained that capitalism does not use available technology and
baseline: In addition, they complained that capitalism does not use available technology and resources to their maximum potential in the interests of the public.

prompts: Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels argued that socialism would emerge from historical necessity
baseline: Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels argued that socialism would emerge from historical necessity as capitalism rendered itself obsolete and unsustainable from increasing internal contradictions emerging from the development of the productive forces and technology.

prompts: It was these advances in the productive forces combined with the old
baseline: It was these advances in the productive forces combined with the old social relations of production of capitalism that would generate contradictions, leading to working-class consciousness.

prompts: Marx and Engels used the terms socialism and communism interchangeably , but many later Marxists defined socialism as a
baseline: Marx and Engels used the terms socialism and communism interchangeably, but many later Marxists defined socialism as a specific historical phase that would displace capitalism and precede communism.

prompts: Marx argued that the material
baseline: Marx argued that the material productive forces (in industry and commerce) brought into existence by capitalism predicated a cooperative society since production had become a mass social, collective activity of the working class to create commodities but with private ownership (the relations of production or property relations).

prompts: Schumpeter argued that there would be different institutions within socialism than those that exist within modern capitalism
baseline: Schumpeter argued that there would be different institutions within socialism than those that exist within modern capitalism, just as feudalism had its own distinct and unique institutional forms.

prompts: The state , along with concepts like property and taxation , were concepts exclusive to
baseline: The state, along with concepts like property and taxation, were concepts exclusive to commercial society (capitalism) and attempting to place them within the context of a future socialist society would amount to a distortion of these concepts by using them out of context.

prompts: For Marxists , the development of capitalism in Western Europe provided a material basis
baseline: For Marxists, the development of capitalism in Western Europe provided a material basis for the possibility of bringing about socialism because according to The Communist Manifesto "hat the bourgeoisie produces above all is its own grave diggers", namely the working class, which must become conscious of the historical objectives set it by society.

prompts: Lenin theorised that under capitalism the workers can not achieve class consciousness beyond
baseline: Lenin theorised that under capitalism the workers cannot achieve class consciousness beyond organising into trade unions and making demands of the capitalists.

prompts: Reformism is the belief that socialists should stand in parliamentary elections
baseline: Reformism is the belief that socialists should stand in parliamentary elections within capitalist society and if elected use the machinery of government to pass political and social reforms for the purposes of ameliorating the instabilities and inequities of capitalism.

prompts: Reformism is criticized for being paradoxical as it seeks to overcome the
baseline: Reformism is criticized for being paradoxical as it seeks to overcome the existing economic system of capitalism while trying to improve the conditions of capitalism, thereby making it appear more tolerable to society.

prompts: According to Rosa Luxemburg , capitalism is not overthrown , " but
baseline: According to Rosa Luxemburg, capitalism is not overthrown, "but is on the contrary strengthened by the development of social reforms".

prompts: In a similar vein , Stan Parker of the Socialist Party of Great Britain argues that reforms are
baseline: In a similar vein, Stan Parker of the Socialist Party of Great Britain argues that reforms are a diversion of energy for socialists and are limited because they must adhere to the logic of capitalism.

prompts: French social theorist André Gorz criticized reformism by advocating a third alternative
baseline: French social theorist André Gorz criticized reformism by advocating a third alternative to reformism and social revolution that he called "non-reformist reforms", specifically focused on structural changes to capitalism as opposed to reforms to improve living conditions within capitalism or to prop it up through economic interventions.

prompts: The counter - cultural phenomenon which emerged in the 1960s
baseline: The counter-cultural phenomenon which emerged in the 1960s shaped the intellectual and radical outlook of the New Left; this movement placed a heavy emphasis on anti-racism, anti-imperialism and direct democracy in opposition to the dominant culture of advanced industrial capitalism.

prompts: The original conception of socialism was an economic system whereby production was organised in a way
baseline: The original conception of socialism was an economic system whereby production was organised in a way to directly produce goods and services for their utility (or use-value in classical and Marxian economics), with the direct allocation of resources in terms of physical units as opposed to financial calculation and the economic laws of capitalism (see law of value), often entailing the end of capitalistic economic categories such as rent, interest, profit and money.

prompts: Economic liberals and right libertarians view private ownership of the means of production and the market exchange as natural entities or moral rights which are central to their conceptions of freedom and liberty and view the economic dynamics
baseline: Economic liberals and right libertarians view private ownership of the means of production and the market exchange as natural entities or moral rights which are central to their conceptions of freedom and liberty and view the economic dynamics of capitalism as immutable and absolute, therefore they perceive public ownership of the means of production, cooperatives and economic planning as infringements upon liberty.

prompts: Anarcho - communism is a theory of anarchism which advocates the abolition of
baseline: Anarcho-communism is a theory of anarchism which advocates the abolition of the state, private property and capitalism in favour of common ownership of the means of production.

prompts: Wolff argues that " re - organising production so that workers become collectively self -
baseline: Wolff argues that "re-organising production so that workers become collectively self-directed at their work-sites" not only moves society beyond both capitalism and state socialism of the last century, but would also mark another milestone in human history, similar to earlier transitions out of slavery and feudalism.

prompts: State socialism can be used to classify any variety of
baseline: State socialism can be used to classify any variety of socialist philosophies that advocates the ownership of the means of production by the state apparatus, either as a transitional stage between capitalism and socialism, or as an end-goal in itself.

prompts: The Chinese economic model is widely cited as a contemporary
baseline: The Chinese economic model is widely cited as a contemporary form of state capitalism, the major difference between Western capitalism and the Chinese model being the degree of state-ownership of shares in publicly listed corporations.

prompts: Mutualists support market socialism , collectivist anarchists favour workers cooperatives and
baseline: Mutualists support market socialism, collectivist anarchists favour workers cooperatives and salaries based on the amount of time contributed to production, anarcho-communists advocate a direct transition from capitalism to libertarian communism and a gift economy and anarcho-syndicalists prefer workers' direct action and the general strike.

prompts: Now this means that we are treading in difficult water
baseline: Now this means that we are treading in difficult water, because it really means that we are saying that something is wrong with capitalism.

prompts: Modern social democracy emphasises a program of gradual legislative modification of capitalism to make it more equitable
baseline: Modern social democracy emphasises a program of gradual legislative modification of capitalism to make it more equitable and humane while the theoretical end goal of building a socialist society is relegated to the indefinite future.

prompts: The major difference between social democracy and democratic socialism is the object of
baseline: The major difference between social democracy and democratic socialism is the object of their politics in that contemporary social democrats support a welfare state and unemployment insurance as well as other practical, progressive reforms of capitalism and are more concerned to administrate and humanise it.

prompts: On the other hand , democratic socialists seek to replace capitalism
baseline: On the other hand, democratic socialists seek to replace capitalism with a socialist economic system, arguing that any attempt to humanise capitalism through regulations and welfare policies would distort the market and create economic contradictions.

prompts: While democratic socialism and social democracy are anti - capitalist positions insofar as criticism of capitalism is linked to the private
baseline: While democratic socialism and social democracy are anti-capitalist positions insofar as criticism of capitalism is linked to the private ownership of the means of production, liberal socialism identifies artificial and legalistic monopolies to be the fault of capitalism and opposes an entirely unregulated market economy.

prompts: Several scholars state that in practice , the Soviet model functioned as a form
baseline: Several scholars state that in practice, the Soviet model functioned as a form of state capitalism.

prompts: The results of a 2019 Axios poll found that 70 %
baseline: The results of a 2019 Axios poll found that 70% of US millennials were willing to vote for a socialist candidate and 50% of this same demographic had a somewhat or very unfavourable view of capitalism.

prompts: Economic liberals and right - libertarians argue that private ownership
baseline: Economic liberals and right-libertarians argue that private ownership of the means of production and market exchange are natural entities or moral rights which are central to freedom and liberty and argue that the economic dynamics of capitalism are immutable and absolute.

prompts: Opponents of this view , including supporters of socialism , state that these killings
baseline: Opponents of this view, including supporters of socialism, state that these killings were aberrations caused by specific authoritarian regimes, and not caused by socialism itself, and  draw comparisons to killings, famines and excess deaths under capitalism, colonialism and anti-communist authoritarian governments.

prompts: The distinction between communism and socialism became salient in 1918
baseline: The distinction between communism and socialism became salient in 1918 after the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party renamed itself to the All-Russian Communist Party, interpreting communism specifically to mean socialists who supported the politics and theories of Bolshevism, Leninism and later that of Marxism–Leninism, although communist parties continued to describe themselves as socialists dedicated to socialism.

prompts: Engels wrote that in 1848 , when The Communist Manifesto was published , socialism was
baseline: Engels wrote that in 1848, when The Communist Manifesto was published, socialism was respectable in Europe while communism was not.

prompts: This branch of socialism produced the communist work
baseline: This branch of socialism produced the communist work of Étienne Cabet in France and Wilhelm Weitling in Germany.

prompts: The Communist Manifesto was written by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels in 1847 - 48 just before the Revolutions of 1848 swept Europe , expressing
baseline: The Communist Manifesto was written by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels in 1847-48 just before the Revolutions of 1848 swept Europe, expressing what they termed scientific socialism.

prompts: In the first half of the 20th century , the Soviet Union and the communist parties of the Third International around the world , came to represent socialism
baseline: In the first half of the 20th century, the Soviet Union and the communist parties of the Third International around the world, came to represent socialism in terms of the Soviet model of economic development and the creation of centrally planned economies directed by a state that owns all the means of production, although other trends condemned what they saw as the lack of democracy.

prompts: For Marxists , the development of capitalism in Western Europe provided a material basis
baseline: For Marxists, the development of capitalism in Western Europe provided a material basis for the possibility of bringing about socialism because according to The Communist Manifesto "hat the bourgeoisie produces above all is its own grave diggers", namely the working class, which must become conscious of the historical objectives set it by society.

prompts: Soviet scholar Robert Bird considered his work as
baseline: Soviet scholar Robert Bird considered his work as the "first systematic treatment of art by a Communist leader" and a catalyst for later, Marxist cultural and critical theories.

prompts: The most prominent example of a planned economy was the
baseline: The most prominent example of a planned economy was the economic system of the Soviet Union and as such the centralised-planned economic model is usually associated with the communist states of the 20th century, where it was combined with a single-party political system.

prompts: The first anarchist journal to use the term libertarian was Le Libertaire ,
baseline: The first anarchist journal to use the term libertarian was Le Libertaire, Journal du Mouvement Social, published in New York City between 1858 and 1861 by French libertarian communist Joseph Déjacque, the first recorded person to describe himself as libertarian.

prompts: Harry Hay was an early leader
baseline: Harry Hay was an early leader in the American LGBT rights movement as well as a member of the Communist Party USA.

prompts: Many commentators on the political right point to the mass killings under communist regimes , claiming them as an
baseline: Many commentators on the political right point to the mass killings under communist regimes, claiming them as an indictment of socialism.

prompts: Opponents of this view , including supporters of socialism , state that these killings
baseline: Opponents of this view, including supporters of socialism, state that these killings were aberrations caused by specific authoritarian regimes, and not caused by socialism itself, and  draw comparisons to killings, famines and excess deaths under capitalism, colonialism and anti-communist authoritarian governments.

prompts: Democratic socialism is a centre - left to left -
baseline: Democratic socialism is a centre-left to left-wing set of political philosophies that supports political democracy and some form of a socially owned economy, with a particular emphasis on economic democracy, workplace democracy, and workers' self-management within a market socialist, decentralised planned, or democratic centrally planned socialist economy.

prompts: Although most democratic socialists seek a gradual transition to socialism , democratic socialism can support revolutionary or reformist
baseline: Although most democratic socialists seek a gradual transition to socialism, democratic socialism can support revolutionary or reformist politics to establish socialism.

prompts: Democratic socialism was popularised by socialists who opposed the backsliding towards
baseline: Democratic socialism was popularised by socialists who opposed the backsliding towards a one-party state in the Soviet Union and other nations during the 20th century.

prompts: The history of democratic socialism can be traced back to 19th
baseline: The history of democratic socialism can be traced back to 19th-century socialist thinkers across Europe and the Chartist movement in Britain, which somewhat differed in their goals but shared a common demand for democratic decision-making and public ownership of the means of production and viewed these as fundamental characteristics of the society they advocated for.

prompts: From the late 19th to the early 20th century , democratic socialism was heavily influenced by the gradualist
baseline: From the late 19th to the early 20th century, democratic socialism was heavily influenced by the gradualist form of socialism promoted by the British Fabian Society and Eduard Bernstein's evolutionary socialism in Germany.

prompts: Democratic socialism may be used broadly ( such
baseline: Democratic socialism may be used broadly (such as all forms of socialism which reject Marxist–Leninism) or more narrowly.

prompts: As a broad movement , it includes forms of social
baseline: As a broad movement, it includes forms of social democracy, libertarian socialism, market socialism, reformist socialism, revolutionary socialism, ethical socialism, liberal socialism, humanist Marxism, state socialism, left populism, Trotskyism, left communism, utopian socialism, and Eurocommunism.

prompts: Democratic socialism is contrasted with Marxism – Leninism , whose opponents often perceive as being authoritarian
baseline: Democratic socialism is contrasted with Marxism–Leninism, whose opponents often perceive as being authoritarian, bureaucratic, and undemocratic in practice.

prompts: Democratic socialism is also distinguished from Third Way social democracy because democratic socialists are committed to the systemic
baseline: Democratic socialism is also distinguished from Third Way social democracy because democratic socialists are committed to the systemic transformation of the economy from capitalism to socialism, while social democrats use capitalism to create a strong welfare state, leaving many businesses under private ownership.

prompts: While having socialism as a long - term goal , some moderate democratic socialists are more concerned about
baseline: While having socialism as a long-term goal, some moderate democratic socialists are more concerned about curbing capitalism's excesses and are supportive of progressive reforms to humanise it in the present day.

prompts: The main criticism of democratic socialism from the perspective of liberal democrats is focused on the compatibility
baseline: The main criticism of democratic socialism from the perspective of liberal democrats is focused on the compatibility of democracy and socialism, while Marxist–Leninist criticisms are focused on the feasibility of achieving a socialist or communist society through democratic means or without suppressing counter-revolutionary forces.

prompts: However , some have argued that following the end of
baseline: However, some have argued that following the end of the Cold War, many of these countries have moved away from socialism as a neoliberal consensus replaced the social democratic consensus in the advanced capitalist world.

prompts: Democratic socialism is defined as having a socialist economy in which the means of production are socially and collectively owned or controlled alongside
baseline: Democratic socialism is defined as having a socialist economy in which the means of production are socially and collectively owned or controlled alongside a democratic political system of government.

prompts: In democratic socialism , the active participation of the population and workers in the self - management of the economy characterises socialism , while
baseline: In democratic socialism, the active participation of the population and workers in the self-management of the economy characterises socialism, while administrative-command systems do not.

prompts: For Hal Draper , revolutionary - democratic socialism is a type of
baseline: For Hal Draper, revolutionary-democratic socialism is a type of socialism from below, writing in The Two Souls of Socialism that "the leading spokesman in the Second International of a revolutionary-democratic Socialism-from-Below was Rosa Luxemburg, who so emphatically put her faith and hope in the spontaneous struggle of a free working class that the myth-makers invented for her a 'theory of spontaneity.'" Similarly, he wrote about Eugene V.

prompts: Debs that " ' Debsian socialism ' evoked a tremendous response
baseline: Debs that "'Debsian socialism' evoked a tremendous response from the heart of the people, but Debs had no successor as a tribune of revolutionary-democratic socialism."

prompts: The Socialist Party of Great Britain and the World Socialist Movement define socialism in its
baseline: The Socialist Party of Great Britain and the World Socialist Movement define socialism in its classical formulation as a "system of society based upon the common ownership and democratic control of the means and instruments for producing and distributing wealth by and in the interest of the community." Additionally, they include classlessness, statelessness and the abolition of wage labour as characteristics of a socialist society, characterising it as a stateless, propertyless, post-monetary economy based on calculation in kind, a free association of producers, workplace democracy and free access to goods and services produced solely for use and not for exchange.

prompts: Although these characteristics are usually reserved to describe a communist society
baseline: Although these characteristics are usually reserved to describe a communist society, this is consistent with the usage of Marx, Friedrich Engels and others, who referred to communism and socialism interchangeably.

prompts: The Democratic Socialists of America ( DSA ) , defines democratic socialism as
baseline: The Democratic Socialists of America (DSA), defines democratic socialism as a decentralised socially-owned economy and rejecting both authoritarian socialism and social democracy, stating:

prompts: We must replace it with democratic socialism , a system where ordinary people have a real voice
baseline: We must replace it with democratic socialism, a system where ordinary people have a real voice in our workplaces, neighborhoods, and society.

prompts: Our vision pushes further than historic
baseline: Our vision pushes further than historic social democracy and leaves behind authoritarian visions of socialism in the dustbin of history.

prompts: Tony Benn , a prominent left - wing Labour Party politician , described democratic socialism as
baseline: Tony Benn, a prominent left-wing Labour Party politician, described democratic socialism as socialism that is "open, libertarian, pluralistic, humane and democratic; nothing whatever in common with the harsh, centralised, dictatorial and mechanistic images which are purposely presented by our opponents and a tiny group of people who control the mass media in Britain."

prompts: Some tendencies of democratic socialism advocate for a social revolution to transition to socialism ,
baseline: Some tendencies of democratic socialism advocate for a social revolution to transition to socialism, distinguishing it from some forms of social democracy.

prompts: In Soviet politics , democratic socialism is the version of
baseline: In Soviet politics, democratic socialism is the version of the Soviet Union model reformed democratically.

prompts: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev described perestroika as building a " new
baseline: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev described perestroika as building a "new, humane and democratic socialism." Consequently, some former communist parties have rebranded themselves as democratic socialists.

prompts: This includes parties such as The Left in Germany , a party succeeding the Party of
baseline: This includes parties such as The Left in Germany, a party succeeding the Party of Democratic Socialism, which was itself the legal successor of the Socialist Unity Party of Germany.

prompts: Some uses of the term democratic socialism represent social democratic policies
baseline: Some uses of the term democratic socialism represent social democratic policies within capitalism instead of an ideology that aims to transcend and replace capitalism, although this is not always the case.

baseline: Page, a reader in Democratic Socialism and Social Policy at the University of Birmingham, wrote about transformative democratic socialism to refer to the politics of Labour Party Prime Minister Clement Attlee and its government (fiscal redistribution, some degree of public ownership and a strong welfare state) and revisionist democratic socialism as developed by Labour Party politician Anthony Crosland and Labour Party Prime Minister Harold Wilson, arguing:

prompts: Social democracy prior to the displacement of Keynesianism by neoliberalism and monetarism , which caused many social -
baseline: Social democracy prior to the displacement of Keynesianism by neoliberalism and monetarism, which caused many social-democratic parties to adopt the Third Way ideology, accepting capitalism as the current status quo and powers that be, redefining socialism in a way that it maintained the capitalist structure intact, has been ocassionally described as a form of democratic socialism.

prompts: The new version of Clause IV of the British Labour Party 's constitution , first adopted by former party
baseline: The new version of Clause IV of the British Labour Party's constitution, first adopted by former party leader Tony Blair, uses democratic socialism to describe a modernised form of social democracy.

prompts: While affirming a commitment to democratic socialism , it no longer commits the party to
baseline: While affirming a commitment to democratic socialism, it no longer commits the party to public ownership of industry and, in its place, advocates "the enterprise of the market and the rigour of competition" along with "high quality public services ... either owned by the public or accountable to them."
