prompts: Busky 's Democratic Socialism : A Global Survey describes social democracy as
baseline: Busky's Democratic Socialism: A Global Survey describes social democracy as a form of democratic socialism that follows a gradual, reformist or evolutionary path to socialism rather than a revolutionary one.

prompts: This tendency is captured in the statement of Labour revisionist Anthony Crosland , who argued that the socialism
baseline: This tendency is captured in the statement of Labour revisionist Anthony Crosland, who argued that the socialism of the pre-war world was now becoming increasingly irrelevant.

prompts: This tendency has been evoked in works such as Roy Hattersley 's Choose Freedom : The Future of Democratic Socialism , Malcolm Hamilton 's Democratic Socialism in Britain and Sweden , and Jim Tomlinson 's Democratic Socialism and Economic Policy : The Attlee Years , 1945–1951 A variant of this set of definitions is Joseph Schumpeter 's
baseline: This tendency has been evoked in works such as Roy Hattersley's Choose Freedom: The Future of Democratic Socialism, Malcolm Hamilton's Democratic Socialism in Britain and Sweden, and Jim Tomlinson's Democratic Socialism and Economic Policy: The Attlee Years, 1945–1951 A variant of this set of definitions is Joseph Schumpeter's argument in Capitalism, Socialism and Democracy (1942) that liberal democracies were evolving from liberal capitalism into democratic socialism with the growth of industrial democracy, regulatory institutions and self-management.

prompts: A key difference is that social democrats are mainly concerned with practical reforms within capitalism , with socialism either relegated to the indefinite
baseline: A key difference is that social democrats are mainly concerned with practical reforms within capitalism, with socialism either relegated to the indefinite future or perceived to have abandoned it in the case of the Third Way.

prompts: More radical democratic socialists want to go beyond mere meliorist
baseline: More radical democratic socialists want to go beyond mere meliorist reforms and advocate the systemic transformation of the mode of production from capitalism to socialism.

prompts: While the Third Way has been described as a new
baseline: While the Third Way has been described as a new social democracy or neo-social democracy, standing for a modernised social democracy and competitive socialism, the form of social democracy that remained committed to the gradual abolition of capitalism and social democrats opposed to the Third Way merged into democratic socialism.

prompts: One distinction to separate the modern versions of democratic socialism and social democracy is that the former
baseline: One distinction to separate the modern versions of democratic socialism and social democracy is that the former can include revolutionary means.

prompts: Many social democrats " refer to themselves as socialists or democratic socialists " , and some " use or have used these terms interchangeably
baseline: Many social democrats "refer to themselves as socialists or democratic socialists", and some "use or have used these terms interchangeably." Others argue that "there are clear differences between the three terms, and preferred to describe their own political beliefs by using the term 'social democracy' only." In political science, democratic socialism and social democracy are occasionally seen as synonymous or otherwise not mutually exclusive, while they are usually sharply distinguished in journalistic use.

prompts: While social democrats continue to call and describe themselves as democratic
baseline: While social democrats continue to call and describe themselves as democratic socialists or simply socialists, the meaning of democratic socialism and social democracy effectively reversed.

prompts: Democratic socialism originally represented socialism achieved by democratic means and usually resulted in reformism ,
baseline: Democratic socialism originally represented socialism achieved by democratic means and usually resulted in reformism, whereas social democracy included reformist and revolutionary wings.

prompts: With the association of social democracy as a policy regime and the development of the Third Way , social democracy became almost exclusively associated with capitalist welfare
baseline: With the association of social democracy as a policy regime and the development of the Third Way, social democracy became almost exclusively associated with capitalist welfare states, while democratic socialism came to refer to anti-capitalist tendencies, including communism, revolutionary socialism, and reformist socialism.

prompts: While most social - democratic parties describe themselves as democratic
baseline: While most social-democratic parties describe themselves as democratic socialists, with democratic socialism representing the theory and social democracy the practice and vice versa, political scientists distinguish between the two.

prompts: According to Steve Ludlam , " the arrival of New Labour signalled an unprecedented and
baseline: According to Steve Ludlam, "the arrival of New Labour signalled an unprecedented and possibly final assault on the  Labour Party's democratic socialist tradition, that is to say the tradition of those seeking the transformation of capitalism into socialism by overwhelmingly legislative means. ...

prompts: Democratic socialists have promoted various different models of socialism and economics , ranging from market socialism
baseline: Democratic socialists have promoted various different models of socialism and economics, ranging from market socialism, where socially owned enterprises operate in competitive markets and are self-managed by their workforce, to non-market participatory economics based on decentralised economic planning, and democratic central planning.

prompts: Democratic socialism can also be committed to a decentralised form of economic planning where productive units are integrated into a single
baseline: Democratic socialism can also be committed to a decentralised form of economic planning where productive units are integrated into a single organisation and organised based on self-management.

prompts: Debs and Norman Thomas , both United States Presidential candidates for the Socialist Party of America , understood socialism to be
baseline: Debs and Norman Thomas, both United States Presidential candidates for the Socialist Party of America, understood socialism to be an economic system structured upon production for use and social ownership in place of the for-profit system and private ownership of the means of production.

prompts: Contemporary proponents of market socialism and decentralised planning have argued that rather than
baseline: Contemporary proponents of market socialism and decentralised planning have argued that rather than socialism itself, the primary reason for the economic shortcomings of Soviet-type economies was their administrative-command system and its failure to create rules and operational criteria for the efficient operation of state enterprises in their hierarchical allocation of resources and commodities.

prompts: A democratically planned economy has been proposed as a basis
baseline: A democratically planned economy has been proposed as a basis for socialism and variously advocated by some democratic socialists who simultaneously reject market socialism and Soviet-type economic planning.

prompts: Supporters of democratic economic planning often reject market socialism on
baseline: Supporters of democratic economic planning often reject market socialism on the basis that it fails to broadly coordinate information and resources according to social needs, and reject the Soviet model-based administrative-command system due to inefficient or undemocratic operation.

prompts: McNally criticises market socialists for believing in the possibility of fair markets based on equal exchanges
baseline: McNally criticises market socialists for believing in the possibility of fair markets based on equal exchanges to be achieved by purging parasitical elements from the market economy, such as private ownership of the means of production, arguing that market socialism is an oxymoron when socialism is defined as an end to wage labour.

prompts: In 1993 , computer scientist Paul Cockshott and economics professor Allin Cottrell proposed in Towards a
baseline: In 1993, computer scientist Paul Cockshott and economics professor Allin Cottrell proposed in Towards a New Socialism a computerised central planning model based on direct democracy and modern technological advances.

prompts: Some proponents of market socialism see it as an
baseline: Some proponents of market socialism see it as an economic system compatible with the political ideology of democratic socialism.

prompts: Democratic socialist advocates of market socialism often support the development of
baseline: Democratic socialist advocates of market socialism often support the development of worker cooperatives, and sometimes market-based sovereign wealth funds.

prompts: Advocates of market socialism , such as Jaroslav Vaněk , argue that genuinely free
baseline: Advocates of market socialism, such as Jaroslav Vaněk, argue that genuinely free markets are impossible under private ownership of productive property.

prompts: Although capitalism has been commonly conflated with the free market , there is a similar laissez
baseline: Although capitalism has been commonly conflated with the free market, there is a similar laissez-faire economic theory and system associated with socialism called left-wing laissez-faire to distinguish it from laissez-faire capitalism.

prompts: Benjamin Tucker is one eminent American individualist anarchist who adopted a laissez -
baseline: Benjamin Tucker is one eminent American individualist anarchist who adopted a laissez-faire socialist system he termed anarchistic socialism as opposed to state socialism.

prompts: Critics of the free market and laissez - faire , as commonly understood , argue that
baseline: Critics of the free market and laissez-faire, as commonly understood, argue that socialism is fully compatible with a market economy and that a genuinely free-market or laissez-faire system would be anti-capitalist and socialist.

prompts: According to its supporters , this would result in the society
baseline: According to its supporters, this would result in the society advocated by democratic socialists, when socialism is not understood as state socialism and conflated with self-described socialist states.

prompts: While socialism is commonly used to describe Marxism – Leninism
baseline: While socialism is commonly used to describe Marxism–Leninism and affiliated states and governments, there have also been several anarchist and socialist societies that followed democratic socialist principles, encompassing anti-authoritarian and democratic anti-capitalism.

prompts: The form of socialism practised by parties such as the Singaporean People 's Action Party during its first few decades in power was pragmatic , as
baseline: The form of socialism practised by parties such as the Singaporean People's Action Party during its first few decades in power was pragmatic, as it its rejection of mass nationalisation characterised it.

prompts: Karl Marx , whose thought influenced the development of democratic socialism , with some endorsing it and others
baseline: Karl Marx, whose thought influenced the development of democratic socialism, with some endorsing it and others rejecting it

prompts: Democratic socialism involves the majority of the population controlling the economy through
baseline: Democratic socialism involves the majority of the population controlling the economy through some democratic system, with the idea that the means of production are owned and managed by the working class.

prompts: The interrelationship between democracy and socialism extends far back into
baseline: The interrelationship between democracy and socialism extends far back into the socialist movement to The Communist Manifesto's emphasis on winning as a first step the "battle of democracy", with Karl Marx writing that democracy is "the road to socialism." Socialist thinkers such as Eduard Bernstein, Karl Kautsky, Vladimir Lenin and Rosa Luxemburg wrote that democracy is indispensable to realising socialism.

prompts: Philosophical support for democratic socialism can be found in the works
baseline: Philosophical support for democratic socialism can be found in the works of political philosophers such as Axel Honneth and Charles Taylor.

prompts: With an emphasis on community and solidarity , democratic socialism can be seen as a way
baseline: With an emphasis on community and solidarity, democratic socialism can be seen as a way of safeguarding this dependency.

prompts: While socialism is frequently used to describe socialist states and
baseline: While socialism is frequently used to describe socialist states and Soviet-style economies, especially in the United States due to the First and Second Red Scares, democratic socialists use socialism to refer to the tendency that rejects the ideas of authoritarian socialism and state socialism as socialism, regarding them as a form of state capitalism in which the state undertakes commercial economic activity and where the means of production are organised and managed as state-owned enterprises, including the processes of capital accumulation, centralised management and wage labour.

prompts: Democratic socialists include those socialists who are opposed to Marxism –
baseline: Democratic socialists include those socialists who are opposed to Marxism–Leninism and social democrats who are committed to the abolishment of capitalism in favour of socialism and the institution of a post-capitalist economy.

prompts: Andrew Lipow thus wrote in 1847 the editors of the Journal of the Communist League , directly influenced by Marx and

baseline: The history of democratic socialism can be traced back to 19th-century socialist thinkers across Europe and the Chartist movement in Britain, which somewhat differed in their goals but shared a common demand for democratic decision-making and public ownership of the means of production and viewed these as fundamental characteristics of the society they advocated for.

baseline: Those democratic socialists believe that the fundamental issues with capitalism can only be resolved by revolutionary means of replacing the capitalist mode of production with the socialist mode of production through a replacement of private ownership with collective ownership of the means of production and extending democracy to the economic sphere in the form of workplace democracy or industrial democracy.

baseline: Social democracy prior to the displacement of Keynesianism by neoliberalism and monetarism, which caused many social-democratic parties to adopt the Third Way ideology, accepting capitalism as the current status quo and powers that be, redefining socialism in a way that it maintained the capitalist structure intact, has been ocassionally described as a form of democratic socialism.

prompts: This tendency has been evoked in works such as Roy Hattersley 's Choose Freedom : The Future of Democratic Socialism , Malcolm Hamilton 's Democratic Socialism in Britain and Sweden , and Jim Tomlinson 's Democratic Socialism and Economic Policy : The Attlee Years , 1945–1951 A variant of this set of definitions is Joseph Schumpeter 's
baseline: This tendency has been evoked in works such as Roy Hattersley's Choose Freedom: The Future of Democratic Socialism, Malcolm Hamilton's Democratic Socialism in Britain and Sweden, and Jim Tomlinson's Democratic Socialism and Economic Policy: The Attlee Years, 1945–1951 A variant of this set of definitions is Joseph Schumpeter's argument in Capitalism, Socialism and Democracy (1942) that liberal democracies were evolving from liberal capitalism into democratic socialism with the growth of industrial democracy, regulatory institutions and self-management.

prompts: A key difference is that social democrats are mainly concerned with practical reforms within capitalism , with socialism either relegated to the indefinite
baseline: A key difference is that social democrats are mainly concerned with practical reforms within capitalism, with socialism either relegated to the indefinite future or perceived to have abandoned it in the case of the Third Way.

prompts: More radical democratic socialists want to go beyond mere meliorist
baseline: More radical democratic socialists want to go beyond mere meliorist reforms and advocate the systemic transformation of the mode of production from capitalism to socialism.

prompts: While the Third Way has been described as a new
baseline: While the Third Way has been described as a new social democracy or neo-social democracy, standing for a modernised social democracy and competitive socialism, the form of social democracy that remained committed to the gradual abolition of capitalism and social democrats opposed to the Third Way merged into democratic socialism.

prompts: According to Steve Ludlam , " the arrival of New Labour signalled an unprecedented and
baseline: According to Steve Ludlam, "the arrival of New Labour signalled an unprecedented and possibly final assault on the  Labour Party's democratic socialist tradition, that is to say the tradition of those seeking the transformation of capitalism into socialism by overwhelmingly legislative means. ...

prompts: Although capitalism has been commonly conflated with the free market , there is a similar laissez
baseline: Although capitalism has been commonly conflated with the free market, there is a similar laissez-faire economic theory and system associated with socialism called left-wing laissez-faire to distinguish it from laissez-faire capitalism.

prompts: While socialism is commonly used to describe Marxism – Leninism
baseline: While socialism is commonly used to describe Marxism–Leninism and affiliated states and governments, there have also been several anarchist and socialist societies that followed democratic socialist principles, encompassing anti-authoritarian and democratic anti-capitalism.

prompts: In 1956 , leading British Labour Party politician Anthony Crosland claimed that capitalism had
baseline: In 1956, leading British Labour Party politician Anthony Crosland claimed that capitalism had been abolished in Britain.

prompts: Although the laws of capitalism still operated entirely as in
baseline: Although the laws of capitalism still operated entirely as in the rest of Europe and private enterprise dominated the economy, several political commentators claimed that during the post-war period, when socialist parties were in power, countries such as Britain and France were democratic socialist states.

prompts: While socialism is frequently used to describe socialist states and
baseline: While socialism is frequently used to describe socialist states and Soviet-style economies, especially in the United States due to the First and Second Red Scares, democratic socialists use socialism to refer to the tendency that rejects the ideas of authoritarian socialism and state socialism as socialism, regarding them as a form of state capitalism in which the state undertakes commercial economic activity and where the means of production are organised and managed as state-owned enterprises, including the processes of capital accumulation, centralised management and wage labour.

prompts: Democratic socialists include those socialists who are opposed to Marxism –
baseline: Democratic socialists include those socialists who are opposed to Marxism–Leninism and social democrats who are committed to the abolishment of capitalism in favour of socialism and the institution of a post-capitalist economy.

prompts: Social democracy underwent various major forms throughout its history and is distinguished between the early
baseline: Social democracy underwent various major forms throughout its history and is distinguished between the early trend that supported revolutionary socialism, mainly related to Marx and Engels, as well as other notable social-democratic politicians and orthodox Marxist thinkers such as Bernstein, Kautsky, Luxemburg and Lenin, including more democratic and libertarian interpretations of Leninism; the revisionist trend adopted by Bernstein and other reformist socialist leaders between the 1890s and 1940s; the post-war trend that adopted or endorsed Keynesian welfare capitalism as part of a compromise between capitalism and socialism; and those opposed to the Third Way.

prompts: In his book Capitalism , Socialism and Democracy ( 1942 ) , Schumpeter emphasised that " political
baseline: In his book Capitalism, Socialism and Democracy (1942), Schumpeter emphasised that "political democracy was thoroughly compatible with socialism in its fullest sense".

prompts: The main criticism of democratic socialism from the perspective of liberal democrats is focused on the compatibility
baseline: The main criticism of democratic socialism from the perspective of liberal democrats is focused on the compatibility of democracy and socialism, while Marxist–Leninist criticisms are focused on the feasibility of achieving a socialist or communist society through democratic means or without suppressing counter-revolutionary forces.

prompts: Although these characteristics are usually reserved to describe a communist society
baseline: Although these characteristics are usually reserved to describe a communist society, this is consistent with the usage of Marx, Friedrich Engels and others, who referred to communism and socialism interchangeably.

baseline: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev described perestroika as building a "new, humane and democratic socialism." Consequently, some former communist parties have rebranded themselves as democratic socialists.

prompts: Social democracy originated as a revolutionary
baseline: Social democracy originated as a revolutionary socialist or communist movement.

baseline: These democratic socialist groups often include communist tendencies, in contrast to social democratic groups which exclude anti-capitalist tendencies.

prompts: The interrelationship between democracy and socialism extends far back into
baseline: The interrelationship between democracy and socialism extends far back into the socialist movement to The Communist Manifesto's emphasis on winning as a first step the "battle of democracy", with Karl Marx writing that democracy is "the road to socialism." Socialist thinkers such as Eduard Bernstein, Karl Kautsky, Vladimir Lenin and Rosa Luxemburg wrote that democracy is indispensable to realising socialism.

prompts: Andrew Lipow thus wrote in 1847 the editors of the Journal of the Communist League , directly influenced by Marx and
baseline: Andrew Lipow thus wrote in 1847 the editors of the Journal of the Communist League, directly influenced by Marx and Friedrich Engels, whom Lipow describes as "the founders of modern revolutionary democratic socialism":

baseline: Some Trotskyist organisations such as the Australian Socialist Alliance, Socialist Alternative and Victorian Socialists or the French New Anticapitalist Party, Revolutionary Communist League and Socialism from below have described their form of socialism as democratic and have emphasised democracy in their revolutionary development of socialism.

prompts: As a political tradition , democratic socialism represents a broad anti
baseline: As a political tradition, democratic socialism represents a broad anti-Stalinist leftist and, in many cases, anti-Leninist strand within the socialist movement, including anti-authoritarian socialism from below, libertarian socialism, market socialism, Marxism and certain left communist and ultra-left tendencies such as councilism and communisation as well as classical and libertarian Marxism.

prompts: In addition , democratic socialism is related to the trend
baseline: In addition, democratic socialism is related to the trend of Eurocommunism originating between the 1950s and 1980s, referring to communist parties that adopted democratic socialism after Nikita Khrushchev's de-Stalinisation in 1956, but also that of most communist parties since the 1990s.

prompts: Similarly , anti - communist academic Richard Pipes argued : " The
baseline: Similarly, anti-communist academic Richard Pipes argued: "The merger of political and economic power implicit in socialism greatly strengthens the ability of the state and its bureaucracy to control the population.

baseline: The history of socialism has its origins in the Age of Enlightenment and the 1789 French Revolution, along with the changes that brought, although it has precedents in earlier movements and ideas.

prompts: The Communist Manifesto was written by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels in 1847 - 48 just before the Revolutions of 1848 swept Europe , expressing
baseline: The Communist Manifesto was written by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels in 1847-48 just before the Revolutions of 1848 swept Europe, expressing what they termed scientific socialism.

prompts: In the last third of the 19th century parties dedicated to Democratic socialism
baseline: In the last third of the 19th century parties dedicated to Democratic socialism arose in Europe, drawing mainly from Marxism.

baseline: In the first half of the 20th century, the Soviet Union and the communist parties of the Third International around the world, came to represent socialism in terms of the Soviet model of economic development and the creation of centrally planned economies directed by a state that owns all the means of production, although other trends condemned what they saw as the lack of democracy.

prompts: In the UK , Herbert Morrison said that " socialism
baseline: In the UK, Herbert Morrison said that "socialism is what the Labour government does" whereas Aneurin Bevan argued socialism requires that the "main streams of economic activity are brought under public direction", with an economic plan and workers' democracy.

prompts: At the turn of the 21st century , Latin America saw a pink tide
baseline: At the turn of the 21st century, Latin America saw a pink tide, which championed socialism of the 21st century; it included a policy of nationalisation of major national assets, anti-imperialism, left-wing populism, and a rejection of the Washington Consensus and the neoliberal paradigm.

prompts: Ideas and political traditions that are conceptually related to modern socialism

baseline: The economy of the 3rd century BCE Mauryan Empire of India, under the rulership of its first emperor Chandragupta, who was assisted by his economic and political advisor Kautilya, has been described as," a socialized monarchy", "a sort of state socialism", and the world's first welfare state.

baseline: Abū Dharr al-Ghifārī (d. 652 CE), a companion of Muhammad, is credited by some scholars, such as Muhammad Sharqawi and Sami Ayad Hanna, as originating a form of Islamic socialism.

prompts: The basis for modern socialism primarily originates with the Age
baseline: The basis for modern socialism primarily originates with the Age of Enlightenment and the accompanying rise of liberalism and the Industrial Revolution.

baseline: The views of Babeuf, Sylvain Maréchal, and Restif de la Bretonne specifically formed the basis for the emerging concepts of revolutionary socialism and modern communism.

baseline: In this period socialism emerged from a diverse array of doctrines and social experiments associated primarily with British and French thinkers—especially Thomas Spence, Charles Fourier, Saint-Simon, Robert Owen.

baseline: Outlining principles for the reorganisation of society along collectivist lines, Saint-Simon, Fourier, and Owens served as the primary advocates for what later became known as Utopian Socialism.

prompts: While Fourier and Owen sought to build socialism on the
baseline: While Fourier and Owen sought to build socialism on the foundations of small, planned, utopian communities, Saint-Simon desired to enact change through a large scale initiative that put industrialists and experts in charge of society.

prompts: Robert Owen was considered the founder of
baseline: Robert Owen was considered the founder of socialism in England.

prompts: Claude Henri de Rouvroy , comte de Saint - Simon ( 1760–1825 ) was the founder of
baseline: Claude Henri de Rouvroy, comte de Saint-Simon (1760–1825) was the founder of French socialism as well as modern theoretical socialism in general.

baseline: After Saint-Simon's death in 1825 his followers, known as the Saint-Simonians, continued to spread and develop his teachings, initiating the widespread use of the terms "socialism", "socialize", "socialization", and "socializing the instruments of labor".

baseline: Beginning in 1832 Bazard and Enfantin began to emphasize the term "socialism" as the word that best represented their system.

baseline: Owen's son, Robert Dale Owen, would say of the failed socialism experiment that the people at New Harmony were "a heterogeneous collection of radicals, enthusiastic devotees to principle, honest latitudinarians, and lazy theorists, with a sprinkling of unprincipled sharpers thrown in".

baseline: The larger community lasted only until 1827, at which time smaller communities were formed, which led to further subdivision, until individualism replaced socialism in 1828.

baseline: William Godwin's anarchism exerted an ideological influence on some of this, but more so the socialism of Robert Owen and Charles Fourier.

baseline: The word socialism first appeared on 13 February 1832 in Le Globe, a French Saint-Simonian newspaper founded by Pierre Leroux.

baseline: There were also currents inspired by dissident Christianity of Christian socialism "often in Britain and then usually coming out of left liberal politics and a romantic anti-industrialism", which produced theorists such as F.D.

baseline: In 1839 the socialist writer Louis Blanc wrote his first work on socialism, the treatise, La Organisation du Travail.

baseline: Pierre-Joseph Proudhon (1809–1865) pronounced that "property is theft" and that socialism was "every aspiration towards the amelioration of society".

baseline: Alexander Herzen was a Russian writer, revolutionary, and the first champion of socialism in Russia.

baseline: His writings contributed to the abolition of serfdom in Russia under Alexander II, and he later became known as the "Father of Russian socialism".

baseline: Herzen initiated the belief that socialism would eventually take hold in Russia using the traditional rural Russian communal villages or mir as a basis for its propagation.

baseline: Influenced by Hegel, he believed that only though revolution could the dialectic be accelerated to bring about socialism, he translated many socialist books into Russian so they could be accessible to Russian speakers and financially supported Proudhon's publications.

prompts: While the use of the term socialism was initially adopted to describe the
baseline: While the use of the term socialism was initially adopted to describe the philosophy of the Saint-Simonians, which advocated the socialized ownership of the means of production, the term was quickly appropriated by working class movements in the 1840s, and in the 19th century the term socialism came to encompass a wide and diverse range of economic policies and doctrines which could include any view from generic opposition against laissez-faire capitalism to the systematic communism of classical Marxism and anything in between.

prompts: In general a view could be deemed as socialism or
baseline: In general a view could be deemed as socialism or socialistic if it advocated for the government to take action that would benefit the lower classes and ameliorate economic and social problems in society.

baseline: According to Sheldon Richman, "n the 19th and early 20th centuries, 'socialism' did not exclusively mean collective or government ownership of the means of production but was an umbrella term for anyone who believed labour was cheated out of its natural product under historical capitalism."

prompts: Prior to the Revolutions of 1848 , communism and socialism had differing religious implications with
baseline: Prior to the Revolutions of 1848, communism and socialism had differing religious implications with socialism being seen as secular and atheistic and communism being seen as religious, leading to Owen preferring the term socialism.

prompts: Because the Saint - Simonians still advocated the socialization of
baseline: Because the Saint-Simonians still advocated the socialization of the means of production, just not all private property, this established an important early distinction between their school of socialism and the communism of rival political groups such as the Neo-Babouvists.

prompts: According to Friedrich Engels , by 1847 socialism , such as that of the Owenites and Fourierists , was considered a respectable ,
baseline: According to Friedrich Engels, by 1847 socialism, such as that of the Owenites and Fourierists, was considered a respectable, middle-class, or bourgeoise movement on the continent of Europe, while communism was considered a less respectable working-class movement associated with organizations such as those led by Wilhelm Weitling and Étienne Cabet.

prompts: Despite this initial preference , the use of the term communism was sparse from the
baseline: Despite this initial preference, the use of the term communism was sparse from the 1860s onward, possibly due to its association with militancy in France and Germany, and instead the terms socialism or social democratic became preferred even by followers of the Marxist tradition.

prompts: Socialism was the word predominantly used by Marxists up until World War I and the Bolshevik Revolution , at which time Vladimir Lenin made the conscious decision
baseline: Socialism was the word predominantly used by Marxists up until World War I and the Bolshevik Revolution, at which time Vladimir Lenin made the conscious decision to replace the term socialism with communism, renaming the Russian Social Democratic Labor Party to the All-Russian Communist Party.

prompts: Marx and Engels developed a body of ideas which they called scientific socialism ,
baseline: Marx and Engels developed a body of ideas which they called scientific socialism, more commonly called Marxism.

baseline: Unlike the utopian socialists, who often idealised agrarian life and deplored the growth of modern industry, Marx saw the growth of capitalism and an urban proletariat as a necessary stage towards socialism.

prompts: For Marxists , socialism or , as Marx termed it , the
baseline: For Marxists, socialism or, as Marx termed it, the first phase of communist society, can be viewed as a transitional stage characterised by common or state ownership of the means of production under democratic workers' control and management, which Engels argued was beginning to be realised in the Paris Commune of 1871, before it was overthrown.

prompts: Socialism to them is simply the transitional
baseline: Socialism to them is simply the transitional phase between capitalism and "higher phase of communist society".

baseline: Beginning in 1896, in a series of articles published under the title "Problems of socialism", Eduard Bernstein argued that an evolutionary transition to socialism was both possible and more desirable than revolutionary change.

baseline: Marx and Engels posed the question: How was the Russian Empire to progress to socialism? Could Russia "pass directly" to socialism or "must it first pass through the same process" of capitalist development as the West? They replied: "If the Russian Revolution becomes the signal for a proletarian revolution in the West, so that both complement each other, the present Russian common ownership of land may serve as the starting point for a communist development."

baseline: Both wings accepted that Russia was an economically backward country unripe for socialism.

baseline: After the 1905 Russian Revolution, Leon Trotsky argued that unlike the French revolution of 1789 and the European Revolutions of 1848 against absolutism, the capitalist class would never organise a revolution in Russia to overthrow Tsarist autocracy, and that this task fell to the working class who, liberating the peasantry from their feudal yoke, would then immediately pass on to the socialist tasks and seek a "permanent revolution" to achieve international socialism.

baseline: In the Soviet Union, from 1924 Stalin pursued a policy of "socialism in one country".

baseline: Brezhnev reacted by announcing and enforcing what became known as the Brezhnev doctrine, which stated: "When forces that are hostile to socialism try to turn the development of some socialist country towards capitalism the suppression of these counter-revolutionary forces becomes not only a problem of the country concerned, but a common problem and concern of all socialist countries." baseline: Socialist governments established the mixed economy with partial nationalisations and social welfare.

baseline: In Iran, Mazdak (died c. 524 or 528 CE), a priest and political reformer, preached and instituted a religiously based socialist or proto-socialist system in the Zoroastrian context of Sassanian Persia.

prompts: In the post - revolutionary period in the decade after the French Revolution of 1789 , activists and theorists like François - Noël Babeuf and Philippe Buonarroti spread egalitarian ideas that
baseline: In the post-revolutionary period in the decade after the French Revolution of 1789, activists and theorists like François-Noël Babeuf and Philippe Buonarroti spread egalitarian ideas that would later influence the early French labour and socialist movements.

prompts: Early-19th - century followers of the utopian theories of such thinkers as Owen , Saint - Simon and Fourier could use the terms co
baseline: Early-19th-century followers of the utopian theories of such thinkers as Owen, Saint-Simon and Fourier could use the terms co-operative, mutualist, associationist, societarian, phalansterian, agrarianist, and radical to describe their beliefs along with the later term socialist.

prompts: The English word " socialist " in its modern sense relates to Owenite thought
baseline: The English word "socialist" in its modern sense relates to Owenite thought and dates from at least 1822.

prompts: The Saint - Simonian book Exposition de la doctrine de Saint - Simon , published in two volumes
baseline: The Saint-Simonian book Exposition de la doctrine de Saint-Simon, published in two volumes from 1828 to 1830 and featuring condensed speeches by Bazard and Enfantin, proved to be a landmark in socialist theory.

prompts: Because of their emphasis on labor they summed up their socialist
baseline: Because of their emphasis on labor they summed up their socialist program with principle "To each according to his ability and to each ability according to its work." They also introduced the idea that class antagonism between the workers and owners came from the dispute over possession of the instruments of labor.

prompts: According to John Stuart Mill writing in 1848 the Saint - Simonians had , " sowed
baseline: According to John Stuart Mill writing in 1848 the Saint-Simonians had," sowed the seeds of all the socialist tendencies."

prompts: François Marie Charles Fourier ( 1772–1837 ) was a French utopian
baseline: François Marie Charles Fourier (1772–1837) was a French utopian socialist and philosopher.

prompts: Leaving England for the United States , Robert Owen and his sons began an experiment with
baseline: Leaving England for the United States, Robert Owen and his sons began an experiment with a socialist community in New Harmony, Indiana in 1825.

prompts: Leroux , a Christian socialist , saw individualism as the
baseline: Leroux, a Christian socialist, saw individualism as the primary moral sickness plaguing society.

prompts: The French politician Philippe Buchez became the leader of
baseline: The French politician Philippe Buchez became the leader of the Christian socialist movement in France during the 1830s.

prompts: In 1839 the socialist writer Louis Blanc wrote his first work
baseline: In 1839 the socialist writer Louis Blanc wrote his first work on socialism, the treatise, La Organisation du Travail.

prompts: Proudhon himself , Benjamin Tucker , and others developed these ideas in
baseline: Proudhon himself, Benjamin Tucker, and others developed these ideas in a mutualist direction, while Mikhail Bakunin (1814–1876), Peter Kropotkin (1842–1921), and others adapted Proudhon's ideas in a more conventionally socialist direction.

prompts: Mikhail Bakunin ( 1814–1876 ) , the father of modern anarchism , was a libertarian socialist
baseline: Mikhail Bakunin (1814–1876), the father of modern anarchism, was a libertarian socialist, a theory by which the workers would directly manage the means of production through their own productive associations.

prompts: Influenced by Hegel , he believed that only though revolution could the dialectic be accelerated to bring about
baseline: Influenced by Hegel, he believed that only though revolution could the dialectic be accelerated to bring about socialism, he translated many socialist books into Russian so they could be accessible to Russian speakers and financially supported Proudhon's publications.

prompts: In 1830 , the two leaders of socialist group the Saint - Simonians , Amand Bazard and Barthélemy Enfantin , denounced communism to the
baseline: In 1830, the two leaders of socialist group the Saint-Simonians, Amand Bazard and Barthélemy Enfantin, denounced communism to the French Chamber of Deputies.

prompts: Rousseau is credited with influencing socialist thought , but it was François - Noël Babeuf , and his Conspiracy of Equals , who is credited with providing a
baseline: Rousseau is credited with influencing socialist thought, but it was François-Noël Babeuf, and his Conspiracy of Equals, who is credited with providing a model for left-wing and communist movements of the 19th century.

prompts: Marx and Engels drew from these socialist or communist ideas born in the French
baseline: Marx and Engels drew from these socialist or communist ideas born in the French revolution, as well as from the German philosophy of Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel, and British political economy, particularly that of Adam Smith and David Ricardo.

prompts: Marx and Engels formulated theories regarding the practical way of achieving and running a
baseline: Marx and Engels formulated theories regarding the practical way of achieving and running a socialist system, which they saw as only being achieved by those who produce the wealth in society, the toilers, workers or "proletariat", gaining common ownership of their workplaces, the means of producing wealth.

prompts: When the socialist state ( the dictatorship of the proletariat ) naturally withers away , what
baseline: When the socialist state (the dictatorship of the proletariat) naturally withers away, what will remain is a society in which human beings no longer suffer from alienation and "all the springs of co-operative wealth flow more abundantly".

prompts: According to Marx and Engels , once a socialist society had been ushered in , the
baseline: According to Marx and Engels, once a socialist society had been ushered in, the state would begin to "wither away" and humanity would be in control of its own destiny for the first time.

prompts: The First International became the first major international forum for the promulgation of socialist ideas , uniting diverse revolutionary currents
baseline: The First International became the first major international forum for the promulgation of socialist ideas, uniting diverse revolutionary currents including French followers of Proudhon, Blanquists, Philadelphes, English trade unionists, socialists and social democrats.

prompts: They allied themselves with the federalist socialist sections of the International , who advocated the revolutionary overthrow
baseline: They allied themselves with the federalist socialist sections of the International, who advocated the revolutionary overthrow of the state and the collectivisation of property.

prompts: In Austria , France and other European countries , socialist parties and anarchists played a prominent role
baseline: In Austria, France and other European countries, socialist parties and anarchists played a prominent role in forming and building up trade unions, especially from the 1870s on wards.

prompts: At first , the collectivists worked with the Marxists to push the First International
baseline: At first, the collectivists worked with the Marxists to push the First International in a more revolutionary socialist direction.

prompts: Following the 1871 Paris Commune , the socialist movement , as the whole of the workers ' movement , was decapitated and deeply affected
baseline: Following the 1871 Paris Commune, the socialist movement, as the whole of the workers' movement, was decapitated and deeply affected for years.

prompts: According to Marx and Engels , for a few weeks the Paris Commune provided a glimpse of
baseline: According to Marx and Engels, for a few weeks the Paris Commune provided a glimpse of a socialist society before it was brutally suppressed by the French government.

prompts: In 1889 , on the centennial of the French Revolution of 1789 , the Second International was founded , with 384
baseline: In 1889, on the centennial of the French Revolution of 1789, the Second International was founded, with 384 delegates from 20 countries representing about 300 labour and socialist organisations.

prompts: Despite its illegality due to the Anti - Socialist Laws of 1878 , the Social Democratic Party of Germany 's use of the limited universal male suffrage were " potent " new methods of struggle which demonstrated their growing strength
baseline: Despite its illegality due to the Anti-Socialist Laws of 1878, the Social Democratic Party of Germany's use of the limited universal male suffrage were "potent" new methods of struggle which demonstrated their growing strength and forced the dropping of the Anti-Socialist legislation in 1890, Engels argued.

prompts: Marx believed that it was possible to have a peaceful socialist
baseline: Marx believed that it was possible to have a peaceful socialist transformation in England, although the British ruling class would then revolt against such a victory.

prompts: However , eight years after Marx 's death , Engels argued that it was
baseline: However, eight years after Marx's death, Engels argued that it was possible to achieve a peaceful socialist revolution in France, too.

prompts: After the 1905 Russian Revolution , Leon Trotsky argued that unlike the
baseline: After the 1905 Russian Revolution, Leon Trotsky argued that unlike the French revolution of 1789 and the European Revolutions of 1848 against absolutism, the capitalist class would never organise a revolution in Russia to overthrow Tsarist autocracy, and that this task fell to the working class who, liberating the peasantry from their feudal yoke, would then immediately pass on to the socialist tasks and seek a "permanent revolution" to achieve international socialism.

prompts: Debs to form the Socialist Party
baseline: Debs to form the Socialist Party of America.

prompts: In 1910 , the Sewer Socialists , the main group of American socialists , elected Victor Berger as
baseline: In 1910, the Sewer Socialists, the main group of American socialists, elected Victor Berger as a socialist member of the United States House of Representatives and Emil Seidel as a socialist mayor of Milwaukee, Wisconsin, most of the other elected city officials being socialist as well.

prompts: This Socialist Party of America membership grew to 150,000 in
baseline: This Socialist Party of America membership grew to 150,000 in 1912.

prompts: Debs received 5.99 % of the popular vote ( a total of 901,551 votes ) , while his total of 913,693 votes in the 1920 campaign , although smaller percentage - wise , remains the all -
baseline: Debs received 5.99% of the popular vote (a total of 901,551 votes), while his total of 913,693 votes in the 1920 campaign, although smaller percentage-wise, remains the all-time high for a Socialist Party candidate in the United States.

prompts: Socialist mayor Daniel Hoan , was elected in 1916 and
baseline: Socialist mayor Daniel Hoan, was elected in 1916 and stayed in office until 1940.

prompts: But in 1879 , at the Marseille Congress , workers ' associations created the Federation of
baseline: But in 1879, at the Marseille Congress, workers' associations created the Federation of the Socialist Workers of France.

prompts: The Federation of the Socialist Workers of France was termed " possibilist "
baseline: The Federation of the Socialist Workers of France was termed "possibilist" because it advocated gradual reforms, whereas the French Workers' Party promoted Marxism.

prompts: The Social Democratic Party of Germany ( SPD ) became the largest and
baseline: The Social Democratic Party of Germany (SPD) became the largest and most powerful socialist party in Europe, despite working illegally until the anti-socialist laws were dropped in 1890.

prompts: Marx believed that it was possible to have a peaceful socialist
baseline: Marx believed that it was possible to have a peaceful socialist revolution in England, America and the Netherlands, but not in France, where he believed there had been "perfected ... an enormous bureaucratic and military organisation, with its ingenious state machinery" which must be forcibly overthrown.

prompts: However , eight years after Marx 's death , Engels regarded it possible to
baseline: However, eight years after Marx's death, Engels regarded it possible to achieve a peaceful socialist revolution in France, too.

prompts: These were parties largely formed by and controlled by the trade
baseline: These were parties largely formed by and controlled by the trade unions, rather than formed by groups of socialist activists who then appealed to the workers for support.

prompts: In Britain the Labour Party , ( at first the Labour Representation Committee ) was established by representatives of
baseline: In Britain the Labour Party, (at first the Labour Representation Committee) was established by representatives of trade unions together with affiliated socialist parties, principally the Independent Labour Party but also for a time the avowedly Marxist Social Democratic Federation and other groups, such as the Fabians.

prompts: On 1 December 1899 Anderson Dawson of the Australian Labor Party became the Premier of
baseline: On 1 December 1899 Anderson Dawson of the Australian Labor Party became the Premier of Colony of Queensland forming the world's first parliamentary socialist government .

prompts: The British Labour Party adopted a specifically socialist
baseline: The British Labour Party adopted a specifically socialist constitution (‘Clause four, Part four’) in 1918.

prompts: Many European socialist leaders supported their respective governments
baseline: Many European socialist leaders supported their respective governments' war aims.

prompts: The parliamentary leaderships of the socialist parties of Germany , France , Belgium and Britain each voted to support the
baseline: The parliamentary leaderships of the socialist parties of Germany, France, Belgium and Britain each voted to support the war aims of their country's governments, although some leaders, like Ramsay MacDonald in Britain and Karl Liebknecht in Germany, opposed the war from the start.

prompts: This conference saw the beginning of the end of the uneasy coexistence of revolutionary socialists with the social democrats , and by 1917 war - weariness led to splits in
baseline: This conference saw the beginning of the end of the uneasy coexistence of revolutionary socialists with the social democrats, and by 1917 war-weariness led to splits in several socialist parties, notably the German Social Democrats, and the collapse of the Second International.

prompts: The Russian Revolution of October 1917 brought about the definitive
baseline: The Russian Revolution of October 1917 brought about the definitive ideological division between Communists as denoted with a capital "C" on the one hand and other communist and socialist trends such as anarcho-communists and social democrats, on the other.

prompts: After the October 1917 Russian revolution , led by Lenin and
baseline: After the October 1917 Russian revolution, led by Lenin and Trotsky, consolidated power in the Soviets, Lenin declared "Long live the world socialist revolution!".

prompts: In the chaotic circumstances of postwar Europe , with the socialist parties divided and discredited ,
baseline: In the chaotic circumstances of postwar Europe, with the socialist parties divided and discredited, Communist revolutions across Europe seemed a possibility.

prompts: Communist parties were formed , often from minority or majority factions in most of the world 's socialist parties , which broke away in support
baseline: Communist parties were formed, often from minority or majority factions in most of the world's socialist parties, which broke away in support of the Leninist model.

prompts: In this period few Communists doubted , least of all Lenin and Trotsky , that successful socialist revolutions carried out by the
baseline: In this period few Communists doubted, least of all Lenin and Trotsky, that successful socialist revolutions carried out by the working classes of the most developed capitalist counties were essential to the success of the socialism, and therefore to the success of socialism in Russia in particular.

prompts: But the prolonged revolutionary period in Germany did not bring a socialist revolution
baseline: But the prolonged revolutionary period in Germany did not bring a socialist revolution.

prompts: However , within this line of thought " he tension between anti - vanguardism and vanguardism has frequently resolved itself in two
baseline: However, within this line of thought "he tension between anti-vanguardism and vanguardism has frequently resolved itself in two diametrically opposed ways: the first involved a drift towards the party; the second saw a move towards the idea of complete proletarian spontaneity...The first course is exemplified most clearly in Gramsci and Lukacs...The second course is illustrated in the tendency, developing from the Dutch and German far-lefts, which inclined towards the complete eradication of the party form." In the emerging Soviet state there appeared Left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks which were a series of rebellions and uprisings against the Bolsheviks led or supported by left-wing groups including Socialist Revolutionaries, Left Socialist-Revolutionaries, Mensheviks, and anarchists.

prompts: In response , the Bolsheviks increasingly abandoned attempts to get
baseline: In response, the Bolsheviks increasingly abandoned attempts to get other socialist groups to join the government and instead suppressed them with growing force.

prompts: A " Red Scare " in the United States was raised against the American
baseline: A "Red Scare" in the United States was raised against the American Socialist Party of Eugene V.

prompts: The bureaucracy undermined the democratic and socialist ideals of the Bolsheviks and elevated Joseph Stalin to
baseline: The bureaucracy undermined the democratic and socialist ideals of the Bolsheviks and elevated Joseph Stalin to their leadership after Lenin's death.

prompts: By the mid-1920s , the impetus had gone out of the
baseline: By the mid-1920s, the impetus had gone out of the revolutionary forces in Europe and the national reformist socialist parties had regained their dominance over the working-class movement in most countries.

prompts: For " many Marxian libertarian socialists , the political bankruptcy of socialist orthodoxy necessitated a theoretical break
baseline: For "many Marxian libertarian socialists, the political bankruptcy of socialist orthodoxy necessitated a theoretical break.

prompts: Karl Korsch ... remained a libertarian socialist
baseline: Karl Korsch... remained a libertarian socialist for a large part of his life and because of the persistent urge towards theoretical openness in his work.

prompts: Hitler 's regime swiftly destroyed both the German Communist Party and the Social Democratic Party , the worst blow the world socialist
baseline: Hitler's regime swiftly destroyed both the German Communist Party and the Social Democratic Party, the worst blow the world socialist movement had ever suffered.

prompts: The socialist parties were at first suspicious , given the bitter hostility
baseline: The socialist parties were at first suspicious, given the bitter hostility of the 1920s, but eventually effective Popular Fronts were formed in both France and Spain.

prompts: A vote was won committing the Labour Party committee of the Trades Union Congress to arrange " direct industrial
baseline: A vote was won committing the Labour Party committee of the Trades Union Congress to arrange "direct industrial action" to "stop capitalist attacks upon the Socialist Republics of Russia and Hungary." The threat of immediate strike action forced the Conservative-led coalition government to abandon its intervention in Russia.

prompts: Albert Einstein advocated for a socialist planned economy with his
baseline: Albert Einstein advocated for a socialist planned economy with his 1949 article "Why Socialism?"

prompts: In the United States , the Communist Party USA was formed in 1919 from
baseline: In the United States, the Communist Party USA was formed in 1919 from former adherents of the Socialist Party of America.

prompts: In the 1930s , the Social Democratic Party of Germany ( SPD ) , a reformist socialist political party that was up to then based upon revisionist Marxism
baseline: In the 1930s, the Social Democratic Party of Germany (SPD), a reformist socialist political party that was up to then based upon revisionist Marxism, began a transition away from Marxism towards liberal socialism beginning in the 1930s.

prompts: Jewish Zionists established utopian socialist communities in Palestine , which were known as kibbutzim ,
baseline: Jewish Zionists established utopian socialist communities in Palestine, which were known as kibbutzim, a small number of which still survive.

prompts: The only socialist parties of any significance able to operate freely were those
baseline: The only socialist parties of any significance able to operate freely were those in Britain, Sweden, Switzerland, Canada, Australia and New Zealand.

prompts: It was refounded as the Socialist
baseline: It was refounded as the Socialist International at a congress in Frankfurt in 1951.

prompts: Since Stalin had dissolved the Comintern in 1943 , as part of a deal with the imperialist powers , this was now the only
baseline: Since Stalin had dissolved the Comintern in 1943, as part of a deal with the imperialist powers, this was now the only effective international socialist organisation.

prompts: Communism falsely claims a share in
baseline: Communism falsely claims a share in the Socialist tradition.

prompts: Socialist ( and in some places Stalinist ) parties also dominated postwar governments in
baseline: Socialist (and in some places Stalinist) parties also dominated postwar governments in France, Italy, Czechoslovakia, Belgium, Norway and other European countries.

prompts: The democratic socialist parties of Eastern Europe , however , were destroyed when Stalin imposed
baseline: The democratic socialist parties of Eastern Europe, however, were destroyed when Stalin imposed so-called "Communist" regimes in these countries.

prompts: The first socialist government of Canada and one of the most influential came to power in
baseline: The first socialist government of Canada and one of the most influential came to power in the province of Saskatchewan in 1944.

prompts: They were termed ' socialist ' by all in 1945 , but in the UK , for instance , where Social Democracy had a large majority
baseline: They were termed 'socialist' by all in 1945, but in the UK, for instance, where Social Democracy had a large majority in the Parliament of the United Kingdom, "The government had not the smallest intention of bringing in the 'common ownership of the means of production, distribution and exchange'" as written in Clause 4 of the Labour Party constitution.

prompts: West German Chancellor Willy Brandt has been identified as a liberal
baseline: West German Chancellor Willy Brandt has been identified as a liberal socialist.

prompts: At the same time , the wartime alliance between the Soviet Union and the west broke down from 1946
baseline: At the same time, the wartime alliance between the Soviet Union and the west broke down from 1946 onward, and relations between the Communist parties and the democratic socialist parties broke down in parallel.

prompts: The imposition of Stalinist regimes in Poland , Hungary and Czechoslovakia not only destroyed the socialist parties
baseline: The imposition of Stalinist regimes in Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia not only destroyed the socialist parties in those countries, it also produced a reaction against socialism in general.

prompts: The long postwar boom and the rapid expansion of higher education produced , as well
baseline: The long postwar boom and the rapid expansion of higher education produced, as well as rising living standards for the industrial working class, a mass university-educated white collar workforce, nevertheless began to break down the old socialist-versus-conservative polarity of European politics.

prompts: This new white - collar workforce , some claimed , was less
baseline: This new white-collar workforce, some claimed, was less interested in traditional socialist policies such as state ownership and more interested expanded personal freedom and liberal social policies.

prompts: Some socialist parties reacted more flexibly and successfully to these changes than others , but eventually the leaderships of all social democracies in Europe moved to an explicitly
baseline: Some socialist parties reacted more flexibly and successfully to these changes than others, but eventually the leaderships of all social democracies in Europe moved to an explicitly pro-capitalist stance.

prompts: Symbolically in the UK , the socialist clause , Clause four , was removed from the Labour
baseline: Symbolically in the UK, the socialist clause, Clause four, was removed from the Labour Party constitution, in 1995.

prompts: Some parties reacted to these changes by engaging in a new
baseline: Some parties reacted to these changes by engaging in a new round of revisionist re-assessment of socialist ideology, and adopting a neo-liberal outlook.

prompts: Julius Nyerere was inspired by Fabian socialist
baseline: Julius Nyerere was inspired by Fabian socialist ideals.

prompts: In the mid-20th century some libertarian socialist groups emerged from disagreements with
baseline: In the mid-20th century some libertarian socialist groups emerged from disagreements with Trotskyism which presented itself as Leninist anti-stalinism.

prompts: In the 1970s , as particularly the far left Trotskyist groups continued
baseline: In the 1970s, as particularly the far left Trotskyist groups continued to grow, the socialist and Communist parties again sought to channel people's anger back into safe confines, as they did in 1945.

prompts: In France François Mitterrand buried the corpse of the old socialist party , the SFIO , and founded a new Socialist
baseline: In France François Mitterrand buried the corpse of the old socialist party, the SFIO, and founded a new Socialist Party in 1971, although it would take him a decade to lead it to power.

prompts: The New Left 's critique of the Old Left 's authoritarianism was associated with a strong
baseline: The New Left's critique of the Old Left's authoritarianism was associated with a strong interest in personal liberty, autonomy (see the thinking of Cornelius Castoriadis) and led to a rediscovery of older socialist traditions, such as left communism, council communism, and the Industrial Workers of the World.

prompts: Autonomist Marxism , Neo - Marxism and Situationist theory are also regarded as being anti
baseline: Autonomist Marxism, Neo-Marxism and Situationist theory are also regarded as being anti-authoritarian variants of Marxism that are firmly within the libertarian socialist tradition.

prompts: A New York Times editorial on February 17 , 1975 , stated " a communist
baseline: A New York Times editorial on February 17, 1975, stated "a communist takeover of Portugal might encourage a similar trend in Italy and France, create problems in Greece and Turkey, affect the succession in Spain and Yugoslavia and send tremors throughout Western Europe." The Greek military dictatorship fell in Greece, PASOK arose at first with a strong socialist outlook, and in Spain, the Spanish State fell in a period of rising struggle.

prompts: By the late 1960s , the people of several Eastern bloc countries had become discontented with the human
baseline: By the late 1960s, the people of several Eastern bloc countries had become discontented with the human and economic costs of the Soviet system, the Czechoslovak Socialist Republic especially so.

prompts: Brezhnev reacted by announcing and enforcing what became known as the Brezhnev
baseline: Brezhnev reacted by announcing and enforcing what became known as the Brezhnev doctrine, which stated: "When forces that are hostile to socialism try to turn the development of some socialist country towards capitalism the suppression of these counter-revolutionary forces becomes not only a problem of the country concerned, but a common problem and concern of all socialist countries." In August 1968, pursuant to this announcement, Soviet Armed Forces troops occupied Czechoslovakia.

prompts: Since the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez as president in Venezuela and the beginnings of his " Bolivarian Revolution " aimed at creating greater
baseline: Since the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez as president in Venezuela and the beginnings of his "Bolivarian Revolution" aimed at creating greater equality, Latin American nations saw a tide of democratically elected socialist and centre-left governments emerge.

prompts: Chavez is joined by the democratic socialist president of Bolivia , Evo Morales ( that nation 's first indigenous leader ) , who adopted strong reformist agendas
baseline: Chavez is joined by the democratic socialist president of Bolivia, Evo Morales (that nation's first indigenous leader), who adopted strong reformist agendas and attracted overwhelming majority electoral victories.

prompts: In Colombia 's previous presidential elections , Carlos Gaviria Díaz of the socialist Alternative Democratic Pole came in second place
baseline: In Colombia's previous presidential elections, Carlos Gaviria Díaz of the socialist Alternative Democratic Pole came in second place to Álvaro Uribe of Colombia First, a conservative party.

prompts: Other parts of the developing world also saw a rise in
baseline: Other parts of the developing world also saw a rise in radical socialist parties and movements.

prompts: In many developed nations , the rise of Third Way policies and the increase in capitalism and free - market economies has led to the rise
baseline: In many developed nations, the rise of Third Way policies and the increase in capitalism and free-market economies has led to the rise of many new socialist parties.

prompts: They include Sinn Féin in
baseline: They include Sinn Féin in the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland (they also represent the Nationalist constituency of Northern Ireland), The Left of Germany, Syriza in Greece, Podemos in Spain, Left Party of Sweden, Left Alliance of Finland, New Zealand Progressive Party, Socialist Party of Ireland, Socialist Party of the Netherlands, Respect Party of the United Kingdom, Scottish Socialist Party and Québec solidaire in the Canadian province of Quebec.

prompts: The Progressive Alliance is a political international founded on 22 May
baseline: The Progressive Alliance is a political international founded on 22 May 2013 by political parties, the majority of whom are current or former members of the Socialist International.

prompts: The organisation states the aim of becoming the global network
baseline: The organisation states the aim of becoming the global network of "the progressive, democratic, social-democratic, socialist and labour movement".

prompts: In South Africa the African National Congress ( ANC ) abandoned its partial socialist
baseline: In South Africa the African National Congress (ANC) abandoned its partial socialist allegiances after taking power and followed a standard neoliberal route.

prompts: In Asia , states with socialist economies — such as the People 's Republic of China , North Korea , Laos and Vietnam — have largely moved away from centralised
baseline: In Asia, states with socialist economies—such as the People's Republic of China, North Korea, Laos and Vietnam—have largely moved away from centralised economic planning in the 21st century, placing a greater emphasis on markets.

prompts: They use state - owned corporate management models as opposed to modelling socialist
baseline: They use state-owned corporate management models as opposed to modelling socialist enterprise on traditional management styles employed by government agencies.

prompts: Elsewhere in Asia , some elected socialist parties and communist parties remain prominent , particularly
baseline: Elsewhere in Asia, some elected socialist parties and communist parties remain prominent, particularly in India and Nepal.

prompts: In Malaysia , the Socialist Party of Malaysia got its first Member
baseline: In Malaysia, the Socialist Party of Malaysia got its first Member of Parliament, Michael Jeyakumar Devaraj, after the 2008 general election.

prompts: The objectives of the Party of European Socialists , the European Parliament 's socialist and social democratic bloc , are now " to
baseline: The objectives of the Party of European Socialists, the European Parliament's socialist and social democratic bloc, are now "to pursue international aims in respect of the principles on which the European Union is based, namely principles of freedom, equality, solidarity, democracy, respect of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, and respect for the Rule of Law".

prompts: As a result , today the rallying cry of the
baseline: As a result, today the rallying cry of the French Revolution—Liberté, égalité, fraternité—is promoted as essential socialist values.

prompts: To the left of the PES at the European level is the Party of
baseline: To the left of the PES at the European level is the Party of the European Left (PEL), also commonly abbreviated "European Left"), which is a political party at the European level and an association of democratic socialist, socialist and communist political parties in the European Union and other European countries.

prompts: Alexis Tsipras , socialist Prime Minister of Greece who led the Coalition of
baseline: Alexis Tsipras, socialist Prime Minister of Greece who led the Coalition of the Radical Left (SYRIZA) through a victory in the January 2015 Greek legislative election

prompts: The socialist Left Party in Germany grew in popularity due
baseline: The socialist Left Party in Germany grew in popularity due to dissatisfaction with the increasingly neoliberal policies of the SPD, becoming the fourth biggest party in parliament in the general election on 27 September 2009.

prompts: In Ireland , in the 2009 European election Joe Higgins of the Socialist Party took one of three
baseline: In Ireland, in the 2009 European election Joe Higgins of the Socialist Party took one of three seats in the capital Dublin European constituency.

prompts: In Denmark , the Socialist People 's Party ( SF ) more than doubled its parliamentary representation
baseline: In Denmark, the Socialist People's Party (SF) more than doubled its parliamentary representation to 23 seats from 11, making it the fourth largest party.

prompts: In the 2011 Danish general election , the Social Democrats , Socialist People 's Party and the Danish Social Liberal Party formed government , after
baseline: In the 2011 Danish general election, the Social Democrats, Socialist People's Party and the Danish Social Liberal Party formed government, after a slight victory over the main rival political coalition.

prompts: In Norway , the Red - Green Coalition consists of the Labour
baseline: In Norway, the Red-Green Coalition consists of the Labour Party (Ap), the Socialist Left Party (SV) and the Centre Party (Sp) and governed the country as a majority government from the 2005 general election until 2013.

prompts: In the United Kingdom , the National Union of Rail , Maritime and Transport Workers put forward a slate
baseline: In the United Kingdom, the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers put forward a slate of candidates in the 2009 European Parliament elections under the banner of No to EU – Yes to Democracy, a broad left-wing alter-globalisation coalition involving socialist groups such as the Socialist Party, aiming to offer an alternative to the "anti-foreigner" and pro-business policies of the UK Independence Party.

prompts: In the following May 2010 United Kingdom general election , the Trade Unionist and Socialist Coalition , launched in January 2010
baseline: In the following May 2010 United Kingdom general election, the Trade Unionist and Socialist Coalition, launched in January 2010 and backed by Bob Crow, the leader of the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers (RMT), other union leaders and the Socialist Party among other socialist groups, stood against Labour in 40 constituencies.

prompts: The Trade Unionist and Socialist Coalition contested the 2011 local
baseline: The Trade Unionist and Socialist Coalition contested the 2011 local elections, having gained the endorsement of the RMT June 2010 conference, but gained no seats.

prompts: In 2015 , following a defeat at the 2015 United Kingdom general election , self - described socialist Jeremy Corbyn
baseline: In 2015, following a defeat at the 2015 United Kingdom general election, self-described socialist Jeremy Corbyn took over from Ed Miliband as leader of the Labour Party., but when Corbyn lost to Boris Johnson Labour moved to the right.

prompts: The LCR abolished itself in 2009 to initiate a broad anti
baseline: The LCR abolished itself in 2009 to initiate a broad anti-capitalist party, the New Anticapitalist Party, whose stated aim is to "build a new socialist, democratic perspective for the twenty-first century".

prompts: The government of Portugal established on 26 November
baseline: The government of Portugal established on 26 November 2015 was a Socialist Party (PS) minority government led by prime minister António Costa, who succeeded in securing support for a Socialist minority government by the Left Bloc (B.E.), the Portuguese Communist Party (PCP) and the Ecologist Party "The Greens" (PEV).

baseline: Following the 1935 general election, the First Labour Government pursued socialist policies such as nationalising industry, broadcasting, transportation, and implementing a Keynesian welfare state.

baseline: The views of Babeuf, Sylvain Maréchal, and Restif de la Bretonne specifically formed the basis for the emerging concepts of revolutionary socialism and modern communism.

prompts: While the use of the term socialism was initially adopted to describe the
baseline: While the use of the term socialism was initially adopted to describe the philosophy of the Saint-Simonians, which advocated the socialized ownership of the means of production, the term was quickly appropriated by working class movements in the 1840s, and in the 19th century the term socialism came to encompass a wide and diverse range of economic policies and doctrines which could include any view from generic opposition against laissez-faire capitalism to the systematic communism of classical Marxism and anything in between.

baseline: Prior to the Revolutions of 1848, communism and socialism had differing religious implications with socialism being seen as secular and atheistic and communism being seen as religious, leading to Owen preferring the term socialism.

baseline: In 1830, the two leaders of socialist group the Saint-Simonians, Amand Bazard and Barthélemy Enfantin, denounced communism to the French Chamber of Deputies.

baseline: Because the Saint-Simonians still advocated the socialization of the means of production, just not all private property, this established an important early distinction between their school of socialism and the communism of rival political groups such as the Neo-Babouvists.

baseline: According to Friedrich Engels, by 1847 socialism, such as that of the Owenites and Fourierists, was considered a respectable, middle-class, or bourgeoise movement on the continent of Europe, while communism was considered a less respectable working-class movement associated with organizations such as those led by Wilhelm Weitling and Étienne Cabet.

prompts: Despite this initial preference , the use of the term communism was sparse from the

baseline: Socialism was the word predominantly used by Marxists up until World War I and the Bolshevik Revolution, at which time Vladimir Lenin made the conscious decision to replace the term socialism with communism, renaming the Russian Social Democratic Labor Party to the All-Russian Communist Party.

prompts: In the Manifesto of the Communist Party , written in 1848 just
baseline: In the Manifesto of the Communist Party, written in 1848 just days before the outbreak of the revolutions of 1848, Marx and Engels wrote, "The distinguishing feature of Communism is not the abolition of property generally, but the abolition of bourgeois property".

baseline: Because this society has characteristics of both its capitalist ancestor and is beginning to show the properties of communism, it will hold the means of production collectively but distributes commodities according to individual contribution.

baseline: The Frankfurt Declaration took a stand against both capitalism and the Communism of Stalin and stated that "Socialism aims to liberate the peoples from dependence on a minority which owns or controls the means of production.

baseline: Communism falsely claims a share in the Socialist tradition.

baseline: The New Left's critique of the Old Left's authoritarianism was associated with a strong interest in personal liberty, autonomy (see the thinking of Cornelius Castoriadis) and led to a rediscovery of older socialist traditions, such as left communism, council communism, and the Industrial Workers of the World.

baseline: Marx and Engels developed a body of ideas which they called scientific socialism, more commonly called Marxism.

baseline: Marxism comprised a theory of history (historical materialism), a critique of political economy, as well as a political, and philosophical theory.
